content: The only hope is to send someone back in time to prevent the things from being invented, a journey that only Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) is strong enough to undertake. Assisted by Kitty Pryde (Ellen Page), he zips into the past and wakes up in a strange bed with a pretty companion beside him and Roberta Flack on the radio.

It begins with breaking into the 2010 Coachella festival. A penniless Mr. Haney and a friend jump a fence and make it backstage before being ejected. But Mr. Haney gets great shots. Undaunted, he scores a ticket to Bonnaroo, then crashes the Ultra Festival in Miami. A homemade Bonnaroo DVD wins him a spot documenting a Mumford & Sons tour, and Rolling Stone runs one of his photos. An HBO assignment lets him take a side trip to the Glastonbury festival. Ultimately, his path takes him to Austin City Limits and the Grammys.

A smart, sly comedy about what its director, Will Bakke, calls “the power of platforms,” “Believe Me” parodies the machinery of faith-based fund-raising with its heart on its sleeve and its jokes above the belt.

From the start, “Joe” reads as a quasi-biblical parable in which Joe’s good and bad instincts are at war. It leads to a grisly but ultimately anticlimactic showdown in which Joe goes after Willie and Wade, who have joined forces in a kidnapping scheme.

Shah Rukh Khan’s seasoned authority is a steady anchor amid the frantic contrivances, while nationalistic biases (a North Korean team is the principal rival) are somewhat offset by a playful attitude toward gender: Charlie (Mr. Khan) calls his troupe Charlie’s Angels. And if you’ve ever harbored a desire to see Bollywood’s reigning king rehearsing in a tutu, “Happy New Year” is cause for celebration.

The film makes an odd, quick detour to Boston, where we’re told that artists need patrons and collectors, but we’re not introduced to any. The press notes solve this mystery: Most of the artists in this movie — who themselves aren’t named until the very end — are represented by Michelle Wojcik’s Galería Cubana in Boston, which Mr. Donnelly happened into once and which clearly shaped this film’s vision of Cuban art. RACHEL SALTZ

A young actor named Reid Ewing, who might be familiar from “Modern Family,” spends much of the movie running around naked in service to jokes that aren’t funny, and Michael McKean was somehow talked into a degrading small role. Worst of all, the 10 rules of the title are nothing you couldn’t have figured out on your own. The movie doesn’t work even as an instructional video.

The European holdovers from the trilogy’s earlier installments include Xavier’s English wife, Wendy (Kelly Reilly), who was his roommate in “L’Auberge Espagnole” and a love interest in “Russian Dolls.” In “Chinese Puzzle,” Wendy divorces Xavier to marry John (Peter Hermann), a wealthy American, and settle on Central Park South.
1 hour 15 minutes; not rated

Ben’s situation is more complicated and is really at the heart of this sensitive, acutely observed, resolutely nonmelodramatic film. Though he tries to be courteous and considerate, his presence starts to annoy Joey, who sleeps on the bunk below, and Kate, a novelist whose daily writing routine is disrupted by Ben’s chatty, needy presence.

A Chinese swords-and-martial-arts adventure that takes place during the Ming dynasty, “14 Blades” reframes the wuxia epic as another genre peopled by antiheroes with personal codes of honor: the spaghetti western. It’s not a bad fit.

Directed by Andrew Fleming (“Hamlet 2,” “Dick”), from a screenplay by Stephen Zotnowski, the movie acts like screwball comedy, but there are no laughs as Daisy and Jay’s connection lurches toward implausible romance.

“The Lego Movie” captures both the delight and the frustration of this kind of play. The visual environment created by the filmmakers (Phil Lord and Christopher Miller of “21 Jump Street” wrote and directed; the animation is by Animal Logic) hums with wit and imagination. Although the images are computer generated, they move, for the most part, according to the pleasingly herky-jerky logic of hand-guided stop-motion. You are always aware that you are looking at a world of interlocking plastic blocks, an illusion enhanced in the 3-D version of the film. Smoke, sand and water are all made out of Lego, as are high-rise cities, pirate ships, mountains and a zone of free-form fantasy called Cloud Cuckoo Land.

John Leguizamo provides the voice of the bird, Alex, and pairs nicely with Justin Long, who is the voice of Patchi, the tale’s main character. Patchi is a pachyrhinosaurus who starts out as the runt of the litter but is destined for big things. He has a crush on a female named Juniper (Tiya Sircar), and their slowly blossoming romance is essentially a reworking of the one between Simba and Nala, those animated lions.

“The Notebook (Le Grand Cahier)” — the parenthetical French title may be there to distinguish it from that movie with Ryan Gosling and Rachel McAdams — falls somewhere in the middle. Directed by Janos Szasz, it is based on a widely admired novel, written in French, by the Hungarian-born writer Agota Kristof. The book, which has been previously adapted for the stage, and which counts among its fans the Slovenian philosopher Slavoj Zizek, is a flinty parable of brutality and resilience, in which two nameless twins wait out the Second World War at their wicked-witch-like grandma’s house in rural Hungary. The film is mostly faithful to the details and the mood of the book, but it is also muddled and sensationalistic, and superficially shocking rather than profoundly provocative.

With less than 24 hours’ notice, Screen Gems announced that it would cancel Wednesday’s press screenings for “No Good Deed.” Officially, this unusual step was intended to help the studio protect a plot twist. This twist, it turns out, hardly warrants any fuss or curiosity.
Opens on Friday

The lack of surprise is by no means ruinous, but it fits for a movie that quickly comes across as if it was cooked up by film fans who binge-watched some old noirs and thrillers and wanted to see if they could make one, too. The opening image of a snow globe can’t help but suggest “Citizen Kane” (nothing else here does), while some gore-slicked bills may bring to mind “The Grifters” or another literal-minded entertainment in which blood money becomes bloodied money. When the camera then starts moving across an unsettled scene — a phone off the hook, a corpse on the ground — it feels so familiar, you may wonder if Colonel Mustard is lurking in the study.

Expertly gliding his camera around people who love to talk and a filmmaker who loves to let them, the director of photography, Hanania Baer, works to achieve coherence. No one cares that Mr. Baer is wasting his time.

At some point, though, Mr. Byrkit turns one too many corners (characters, meanwhile, begin bustling in and out of rooms like Marx Brothers extras), and what began as a nifty puzzle feels more like a trap. It may be possible to unkink this story, but when characters and performances are as unengaging as these, it’s hard to feel motivated to try. Mr. Byrkit shot the movie — which has a blurred, low-end digital look and a lot of small-screen-ready close-ups — without a script in his living room, setting the performers loose for five days of improvisation. It’s the kind of experiment that may be useful for directors and actors, but here hasn’t led to a satisfyingly realized movie.

The adventure is related partly through the eyes of Carrie Lee, an American lawyer and the sister of the film’s director, Wendy J. N. Lee, causing it to sound too often like an interloper’s travel video. And much is made of the fact that the trekkers picked up litter as they walked: more than 800 pounds. That’s a little more than a pound per person, for 450 miles of walking. Hmm.

Mr. Villeneuve is for the most part less interested in solving that puzzle than exploring its implications, especially for Adam, the first guy we meet. He is a history professor who seems to lead a solitary, disciplined and less than entirely happy life. He lectures his students on Hegel and returns to the spare, high-rise apartment where he is sometimes visited by his girlfriend, Mary (Mélanie Laurent). One night, while watching a DVD, Adam spots an extra who looks exactly like him. After a bit of Internet stalking — and some of the more traditional kind — he finds his way to Anthony, who lives in a better-furnished high-rise apartment with his pregnant wife, Helen (Sarah Gadon).
In Korean, with English subtitles
1 hour 25 minutes

Just days before his wedding, Nikhil finds himself in a bit of a bind: Not only does he need to prove his business savvy, and therefore worth, to his fiancée, but he also must keep her recently returned, long-estranged sister, Meeta, out of sight. It’s a recipe for failure. But in Vinil Mathew’s “Hasee Toh Phasee,” the setup is also the perfect foil to what is an imperfect union.
“Cold Comes the Night” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gun violence, bloody murder and throat throttling.

Produced in conjunction with the nonprofit Fuel Freedom Foundation, “Pump” is less a movie than a webpage in motion. But the arguments have an appealing logic for those concerned about the environment. The film explores America’s dependence on oil, from John D. Rockefeller to the dismantling of the nation’s streetcars, and traces oil’s effects on the broader economy.

A healthy portion of the movie consists of Oren’s making insensitive remarks, which Mr. Douglas at least excels at tossing off. You might fairly ask whether this is now “as good as it gets” for Mr. Reiner — if you can borrow the title of the 1997 hit that this film’s screenwriter, Mark Andrus, wrote with James L. Brooks. Relatable doesn’t have to mean routine, but Mr. Reiner doesn’t always bother to tell the difference, and Oren might not be the only one set in his ways.
Directed by Charles Martin Smith
“Trust Me” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). The dialogue is filled with vituperative profanity.
“The Monuments Men” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It’s a war movie, if mostly a bloodless one.

Besides Mr. Rathbone’s vocals, the film showcases Mr. Holmes, a musician as well as an actor, who does his own piano playing in the movie and also wrote it with Michael Kristoff, who directed. The story becomes less credible as it goes along. Bobby, for instance, appears to need no rehearsal time, yet he can’t figure out how to be a lawyer by day while carving out two hours a couple of evenings a week to be a crooner.

Though the film’s abstractions can alienate, and intellectual connections are sometimes paid for in drained emotional heat, “Mars at Sunrise” is a thoughtful and inventive look at a seemingly endless war. More than anything, the ambivalence written into the roles — and poignantly captured by the performers — seems to suggest that while taking sides is not impossible, it is almost certainly fruitless.

But that is the starting point for “At the Devil’s Door,” a shape-shifting horror film whose main interest comes from its fluctuating point of view. In the opening section, set in 1987, Hannah (Ashley Rickards) learns the consequences of taking that wad of cash. The movie then turns its focus to a real estate broker, Leigh (Catalina Sandino Moreno), who’s trying to sell Hannah’s old house, before passing the narrative baton to Leigh’s sister, Vera (Naya Rivera).

Written and directed by Jeff Baena, this first feature feels sloppily plotted and uncertain of its destination. Seasoned actors are left to yell pointlessly at one another, while Beth and the zombie angle slowly decompose.

Listening to these three swear up a blue streak is amusing for five minutes or so, but that’s about it. The movie does have a story — something about a road rally and a dead father and a financial debt to two shady guys — but it’s ineptly told, without a shred of wit.
Directed by Martin Lund
1 hour 26 minutes

Later, the mystery of Eve’s disappearance will be solved, but the film’s climactic revelations are muffled and matter-of-fact rather than shattering. Mr. Araki’s style blends detachment and sensationalism. He shoots in the bright, lurid colors of melodrama but surveys the agony in front of him with cool serenity. In his films of the ’90s — nihilistic spectacles like “The Living End,” “Doom Generation” and “Nowhere” — this attitude was exciting, even shocking. In “Mysterious Skin,” still his masterpiece, he turned an almost unbearably horrific story of sexual abuse into something haunting and humane. A similar impulse animates “White Bird in a Blizzard,” but its elements don’t really cohere.

The author and filmmaker Marcel Pagnol’s Fanny trilogy — which consists of the plays “Marius” and “Fanny” and the direct-to-film “César” — has been adapted for movies and television several times, most notably in the 1930s, with Pagnol himself as screenwriter. On the basis of a first installment, it’s not entirely clear what this faithful, slightly creaky new rendering, adapted and directed by the actor Daniel Auteuil, has to offer.
LOUDER THAN WORDS

Oh, to have a consuming passion like theirs, you may sigh to yourself, as you study pictures of the golden couple, whose first film together, “Persona,” was a masterpiece. But as the documentary’s subtitle indicates, intimacy as intense and ravenous as theirs has an inevitable component of pain.
Directed by Michael Medeiros
THE HEART MACHINE

Rounding up a familiar chorus of ugly-mug contest contenders, Mr. De Felitta stages a series of stickups that, while undeniably entertaining, never feel remotely perilous. Armed with an Uzi that Rosie has to load for him (“You’re better with mechanics than me!”), Tommy divests doughy mobsters of their wallets and jewelry, nervously spraying bullets from a weapon he can’t control. Initially amused, then irritated, his well-connected victims soon lose patience, especially when a critical list of names becomes part of Tommy’s haul.

Or, as Forster puts it: “ ‘The king died, and then the queen died’ is a story. ‘The king died, and then the queen died of grief’ is a plot.” If the queen dies, and no one knows why until it’s discovered that she died from grief, mystery enters, allowing the plot to suspend the time-sequence and move “as far away from the story as its limitations will allow.”

Scudder — played by the inevitable Liam Neeson, as imposing as the Colossus of Rhodes — is a feeble light in the inexorable darkness. He’s also a familiar type. A former New York cop with a tragedy and too much booze in his past, he now works as an unlicensed private investigator doing “favors” for people. In turn, he accepts “gifts” for his services, as he explains to a prospective client, Kenny Kristo (a convincingly feral Dan Stevens), with a dead wife, Carrie (Razane Jammal). Kristo’s brother, Peter (Boyd Holbrook, nice and twitchy), is an addict who trips on the steps to recovery but has had the wherewithal to reach out to Scudder, having heard his hard-luck story at Alcoholics Anonymous. It’s the hard-boiled version of the meet cute.

The teenage Philomena (Sophie Kennedy Clark) becomes pregnant in 1952 and is sent to a convent in Roscrea, Ireland. She spends several years in virtual slave labor, working in the convent laundry. It is part punishment and part compensation to the nuns who looked after her during childbirth. These prisonlike convent laundries, where shamed parents exiled their “bad” daughters, were the subject of Peter Mullan’s 2002 film, “The Magdalene Sisters,” and of a Joni Mitchell song.

The blondes of the title are Penelope’s sons, Walker and Cody (portrayed by the couple’s real-life children), but the term might also refer to Penelope’s own bleached bob. She is like one of the children. “I don’t think you’re supposed to do this to your mother,” she says quietly as they tie her to a chair while she is preparing to go out.

Lewis’s estranged father, Stanley (Stuart Margolin), stops speaking; to look after him, the family joins his annual Lewis and Clark re-enactment hike. Stanley’s obsession with the American explorers has inspired both his son’s academic research and his hang-ups. (“Remember when you only used to let me eat what I killed?” Lewis asks his dad.)
“Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Animal cruelty.

“Gone Girl” is set in the recessionary present in a small fictional Missouri town, North Carthage. Around the time you meet Nick, Mr. Fincher folds in some typical snapshots of desperate Anytown, U.S.A.: empty shops, vacant streets and homeless people tramping into the void. Nick and his wife, Amy (Rosamund Pike), aren’t headed for Brokesville quite yet, but they’re clinging hard to the status quo. They’re leasing their big, ugly house, and their bank account is running on fumes. The screenwriter, Gillian Flynn, adapting her novel of the same title, was a television critic for Entertainment Weekly who was laid off, and her characters share the same hard-knock fate: Nick, some kind of magazine writer, lost his New York job, as did Amy, who wrote quizzes for women’s magazines. (Was that a job? A. Yes, B. No, C. I doubt it.)

It is one of several scenes in which he mistreats his musicians, many of whom abandon him, beginning with his original gospel group, the Famous Flames. Only Bobby Byrd (Nelsan Ellis), his longtime best friend, returns. They met as teenagers while both were in jail in Toccoa, Ga. After Brown serves his sentence, Byrd persuades his mother to let the young prisoner live with them. Throughout the movie, wives and girlfriends come and go, but their embattled friendship persists, although it, too, is eventually severed.

He’s especially fond of setting up a human value (say, devotion) only to knock it down, kick it in the teeth and then prop it up again for another go-round. Time and again, a pair of characters face off — with each either significantly isolated in the frame or meaningfully crammed into a tense two shot — and talk and then talk some more. In the beginning was the Word; later, came all the human psychodrama.

“Closed Curtain,” as its title suggests, draws on theater as well as film for inspiration. As soon as he arrives, the writer drapes the window in heavy dark cloth, blocking views of sand, sky and water, and turning the house into a black box stage set. The outside world intrudes first in the form of a television news report about the grisly enforcement of a prohibition on dogs in public — the government has declared them “un-Islamic” — that may explain the writer’s worry that his pet will slip out the door. Then the woman (Maryam Moqadam) arrives, and she and the writer begin an awkward, riddling, asymmetrical cohabitation. He wonders who she is and why she is there, while she seems to know quite a lot about him.
“Labor Day” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for brief violence and sexuality.

But “Gravity” and “Interstellar” are both ultimately about the longing for home, about voyages into the unknown that become odysseys of return. And “Interstellar” may take its place in the pantheon of space movies because it answers an acute earthly need, a desire not only for adventure and novelty but also, in the end, for comfort.
1 hour 33 minutes

“Stand Clear of the Closing Doors” is all the more impressive for not overreacting to the catastrophe and making it the main event. It stays with its characters to a wonderfully witty and understated ending.

Pvt. Norman Ellison (Logan Lerman), who has yet to earn a nickname, serves as both the smooth-faced newbie — afraid of dying and appalled by the callousness of his comrades — and as the crew’s designated egghead. Transferred from the typing pool, he reads Hemingway and plays classical piano, and is clearly more sensitive than the others, who are cut from coarser cloth and have been further battered by grueling campaigns in North Africa, Italy and Normandy.

Traveling from the city of Erbil to the Iraqi-Turkish-Iranian borders (a territory known locally as the Kurdish Bermuda Triangle), Mr. Rosebiani pauses frequently to celebrate the sights, sounds and tastes of the journey. Among people plagued by impermanence, a necklace of fresh figs and a plaintive love song are, he suggests, luxuries that should never be taken for granted.

Leaping onto that hoary bandwagon with a very straight face, Hilary Brougher’s “Innocence” (based on Jane Mendelsohn’s 2000 novel) moves to the formulaic beats of the second-rate TV movie, albeit one cloaked in an ultra-glossy sheen. At its center is Beckett (Sophie Curtis), pouty and pale and mourning her dead mother. She’s not too mopey to notice, though, that there’s something very odd about her new school in the Riverdale section of the Bronx: The teachers resemble willowy supermodels, dress like high-end call girls and emit a distinctly Stepford vibration. And, my goodness, this school has a lot of suicides!

While traveling to Budapest, Vienna, Montreal, Ukraine, Romania and Germany, the film, the first feature by Aaron Yeger, presents a range of lucid commentators, some of whom touch upon distant Roma history. But the primary focus here is on the disenfranchisement and ruthless persecution the Roma have long suffered in Europe: in Romania in the mid-1400s, by the Habsburgs in 1500, by Henry VIII and again by the Habsburgs in 1721. (Joanna Goodey, a European Union official, cites a survey indicating that Roma are currently the most frequent victims of discrimination in the union.)

Now, it is true that the story invites such displays of emotion. Terrible things happen: miscarriages, rape, a suicide, the raining of Serbian artillery shells and snipers’ bullets on Sarajevo. But rather than intensify the impact of these intimate and public horrors, Mr. Castellitto’s feverish directing style robs them of credibility. He seems distracted by the compulsion to make beautiful images and announce large and complicated feelings. He has mistaken his own artistic vanity for moral commitment.

Thomas and Vanda are confined, for nearly the entire duration of “Venus in Fur,” in an empty Paris theater. She has arrived late for an audition, stumbling in from the rain-swept street with a burst of excuse-making and oversharing. Thomas, eager to get home to his fiancée and frustrated by the actresses he has seen so far, is unsure whether to indulge Vanda or send her away. He is intrigued that she shares her name with the character in his play, a stage adaptation of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch’s 1870 novel, “Venus in Furs,” though he is also dismayed at her vulgar ignorance of its themes. “It’s S-and-M porn, right?” she asks. (Like most things, this sounds much smuttier in French.) He insists that it’s a great love story. But again, why choose?

Set in a wintry upstate New York and based on a 2007 novel by Christopher Barzak, this unconventional horror movie has little blood but atmosphere to spare. And if the narrative leaves a great deal unexplained, Carter Smith’s slow, seductive direction — perfectly paired with Darren Lew’s queasy, washed-out photography — grounds the actors in a convincingly dreamlike space between past sins and future choices.
1 hour 33 minutes; not rated

The affair begins at a senior center in the picturesque seaside town where Caroline and Philippe have been living comfortably. When Julien (Mr. Lafitte), her instructor at a computer class, puts the moves on her, she is at first more amused than entranced. But once she realizes that he really desires her, she capitulates, and they begin a relationship in which many of the usual dynamics are reversed.

Cramming more than 40 interviews into an unreasonably brief running time, “Smiling Through the Apocalypse” overflows with dishiness. Gay Talese recalls the genesis of “Frank Sinatra Has a Cold.” Tom Wolfe remembers pushing a deadline on the article that gave a name to his collection “The Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby,” and recounts a car ride with Cassius Clay, who later became the subject of the magazine’s controversial “The Passion of Muhammad Ali” cover. Esquire’s pages served as a forum for innovative work from Norman Mailer, Nora Ephron and Diane Arbus.

Working with hushed choirs, tasteful beams of light and an ethereal aesthetic, the director, Randall Wallace, and his cinematographer, Dean Semler, transform their Canadian locations into a verdant prairie poem. This earthly paradise may feed the spirit, but it doesn’t fill the bellies of the pastor (Greg Kinnear) — who doubles as a volunteer firefighter, wrestling coach and carpet hauler — and his picture book family.
“The Fluffy Movie” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Sexual references.

The De Leon’s mastermind is a mysterious, talkative fellow known as the Monarch, an Internet phenomenon played with nutty exuberance by Michael Keaton. Exuberance is not a quality associated with Tobey Marshall (Aaron Paul, best known for his role in AMC’s “Breaking Bad”), a Mount Kisco mechanic who hopes to use the De Leon to settle some scores. A local hot shot named Dino Brewster (Dominic Cooper) stole Tobey’s girlfriend, Anita (Dakota Johnson), and then did some even worse stuff, stuff that wrecked Tobey’s business, landed him in jail and cost the life of one of his friends. Tobey glowers and sighs and speaks in a low, sorrowful rasp.

Yet, in some ways, a subtler story is told through the stronger hand of the film’s cinematographer, Agnès Godard. Ms. Godard, known for her collaboration with the filmmaker Claire Denis, suggests an entire movie with Claudia’s first visit to the household: a five-minute running take that segues from one character to the next with roving shots that are like internal monologues. And the way she shoots and lights the face of Wendy (Wendy Guillén), Martha’s heavyset teenage daughter, hiding under a mop of hair, says just as much as an unexpected scene about her cutting her arms and making drug cocktails.

Much like the larger picture, the introduction switches between art house abstraction and blunt-force action, and opens on a man as beautifully sculptured and silent as a Michelangelo slab. This is Salvo — the word means safe in Italian — an enforcer and sometimes chauffeur for a criminal enterprise. Sprawled on a small bed in an equally undersized room, Salvo is pointedly waiting in the dark, a state that’s at once physical and metaphysical. It’s dawn in Palermo, the gritty Sicilian capital that the directors — Fabio Grassadonia and Antonio Piazza, making a very fine feature debut — turn into a stage for a story that, at times, could be titled “Once Upon a Time in Sicily.”

As the music ebbs, flows and explodes, so do the visuals. For the most part Mr. Ridley avoids big scenes and long speeches, although he does give Jimi some nice cosmic aperçus and trippy philosophical thoughts. And rather than hewing to a strict narrative line, Mr. Ridley takes a generally more fragmented and associative approach to the material. He retells famous stories, like the time that Clapton ceded the stage to Hendrix, but avoids most of the old behind-the-music clichés. Working with his own fine backup, Mr. Ridley narrows in on gestures, catches looks, throws in family photographs, folds in found footage and occasionally freezes the frame. Rockers bow and birds flutter as Jimi watches from the quiet of his own unfathomable depths only to ignite onstage.

In most movies, something happens; in “Archipelago,” many things happen, quietly yet meaningfully. At the picture-perfect house the family has rented, Edward and Cynthia huddle in the cramped stairwell and politely, stubbornly tussle over which bedroom he should take. When Edward enters the small room that he’s insisted on, he almost immediately bumps his head. Later, as the walls metaphorically close in and the family’s reserve begins peeling away, emotions churning like the sea outside, his doggedness on taking this tiny room can feel less like a gesture of good will and more like a self-regarding sacrifice.

The ruling elite — the self-anointed “New Founding Fathers” — justify this yearly cathartic as a kind of collective colonic, a way to flush all the toxins from the body politic. (Well, the movie is set in Los Angeles, that city of detoxifying angels and master cleanses.) The more plausible explanation is that the writer and director, James DeMonaco, like a lot of Americans, read Shirley Jackson’s influential 1948 short story “The Lottery” at an impressionable age. Ritual sacrifice, either of the self or others, may be almost as old as humanity itself, but it’s also enjoying a pop cultural moment, from the purifying spectacle of “The Hunger Games” series to gladiatorial shows like “Dancing With the Stars” and that blood-slicked altar of worship known as “Game of Thrones.”

Unlike Robert S. McNamara, another former defense secretary who sat for a portrait in front of Mr. Morris’s camera (in “The Fog of War”), Mr. Rumsfeld is untroubled by second thoughts or pangs of conscience. At times, the discrepancy between his view of himself and the historical record is almost comical, as when he waves off the suggestion that he was a ruthlessly Machiavellian player in the internecine Republican struggles of the 1970s. He portrays himself both as selflessly loyal and as ferociously independent, and when asked whether he sees himself as the master or the pawn of events answers both and neither. When Mr. Morris wonders if it might have been better to stay out of Iraq — a view now widely held among Americans of both political parties — Mr. Rumsfeld takes refuge in the unknowable. “Time will tell,” he says.

Born in 1908, the sisters, Daisy and Violet, were exploited by various managers even as they became relatively famous. Unlike some sideshow acts, they were not content simply to be gawked at; they entertained, after a fashion, with musical routines and such.

Make no mistake: There is nothing pleasant about “Child of God,”James Franco’s very fine adaptation of Cormac McCarthy’s short, pitiless novel. But then, Mr. McCarthy is a bard of the apocalyptic who, in his unsparing period novel “Blood Meridian” writes that “war is the truest form of divination.” His is no country for old men, to borrow the title of one of his few books that have been turned into a successful film; neither is it a place for bromides about the triumph of the human spirit, one reason most of the screen adaptations have failed. There isn’t a war per se in “Child of God,” just good and (mostly) evil in a Christ story in reverse about a mystery who becomes a man.

Russian roulette is the hobby of choice for Mr. White’s character, John Chapman, a.k.a. Falcon, and in the New York City opening, he rattles a stickup artist at a convenience store with suggestions for improving his killshots.

Neither experiment eases her suffering, which Ms. Hollyman communicates with congealed movements and an unvaryingly flat affect, which match her coldly impersonal home décor. These give the film a sad, dryly eccentric look that stops just short of alienating.

And so they decide to start their own band, only slightly discouraged by the fact that neither plays an instrument. Klara, a cherubic Sid Vicious with a homemade Mohawk, picks up the bass. Bobo, who looks like a precocious German graduate student, grudgingly settles for drums. At school, they recruit a third member, Hedvig (Liv LeMoyne), a Christian whose piety is a minor inconvenience. Klara and Bobo recognize her as a fellow outsider, and she also actually knows how to play the guitar. Their first and best song is an anticonformist anthem called “Hate the Sport.”

Ward, who died in 1989 and whose brainy cartoons were staples of the early space age, has been dishonored by lame live-action movie versions of Rocky and Bullwinkle, George of the Jungle and Dudley Do-Right. Luckily, “Mr. Peabody & Sherman,” about a supersmart dog and his adopted human son, breaks the curse and respects the nutty, nerdy humor of the original. This DreamWorks Animation production, directed by Rob Minkoff (“Stuart Little,” “The Lion King”) from a screenplay by Craig Wright, is not perfect, but it is fast-moving, intermittently witty and pretty good fun.

From its revenge-of-the-nerd narrative to its soaked-in-nostalgia style, “Ping Pong Summer” revisits the 1980s with such slavish affection that you suspect its writer and director, Michael Tully, of being notably transformed during those boom-box-blighted years. The film fairly beams with the afterglow of lost virginity.

Teddy’s elegantly tailored suits hide a chest full of prison tattoos, and his sneering sadism and fastidious diction mark him out for an especially painful death, though the rules of the genre dictate that we’ll have to wait for it. Once he shows up, painful death is pretty much all “The Equalizer” has on its mind. Alina, the innocent, vulnerable pretext for all the killing, pretty much disappears, though one of her colleagues (Haley Bennett) takes a turn in the victim role. Violence against women is handled discreetly, but the men stomp, stab, shoot and bludgeon one another with showy abandon and an almost erotic intensity.

Mr. Jodorowsky, whose noncinematic pursuits include the development of a therapeutic method called psychomagic, is a shamanistic presence in “The Dance of Reality.” He appears as the protector of his younger self and as a kind of tutelary deity, infusing the story of his own life with a potent and implicitly political lesson. “The Dance of Reality” is the work of a highly disciplined anarchist, whose principal weapon against authority is his own imagination.
THE FRONTIER
1 hour 29 minutes; not rated
Directed by Vivien Lesnik Weisman

“A Picture of You,” the feature debut from J. P. Chan, who wrote and directed, looks at one of the less cinematic aspects of grieving: packing up a house after a parent has died. A brother and sister, Kyle (Andrew Pang) and Jen (Jo Mei), spend the weekend at their mother’s Pennsylvania home. Purging her computer, they discover evidence of a romantic life neither wishes to ponder.

This is a familiar gimmick by now, and if you like delayed gratification and rewinding a movie in your head, once you’ve learned the secret, to see if the story made sense, this is a decent example of the genre. If, on the other hand, you find this kind of manipulation annoying, well, this film is annoying.

It is part of the conceit of “Only Lovers Left Alive,” Jim Jarmusch’s latest slow-burn celebration of art, style and aimless conversation, that old Kit Marlowe (a marvelously grizzled John Hurt), one of the original literary outlaws, is alive and well, if a bit weary. Dwelling in a city associated with latter-day writer-renegades like William S. Burroughs and Paul Bowles, Marlowe is Eve’s confidant and mentor. He also supplies her with human blood, since both of them (and Adam too) are vampires.

“The Winter Soldier” becomes progressively less enjoyable once the plot thickens and a menace looms, as Fury moves one chess piece, while Pierce moves another. Captain America doesn’t move much, beyond cars and debris. However appealing, Mr. Evans remains a recessive screen presence, and while it may be a relief that Captain America isn’t angst-ridden, he’s blandly well adjusted for a guy who, in his last movie, emerged from a decades-long deep freeze. Comic-book movie directors have to sell the prepackaged goods while trying to capture — and maybe redefine, as Christopher Nolan did with Batman — a superhero’s essence. And they have to do so without boring everyone who could not care less why a crusader went dark as night or that he died only to be reborn. But what if he’s kind of dull?

The film’s on-the-ground approach is impressive, including a visit to a radio station, where a worker must put up with ominous, anonymous cellphone calls. But it’s never quite as incisive as another (yet to be released) hijack documentary, “The Captain and His Pirate.” This film could have been more surely and deftly put together.

“The Galapagos Affair” would be a much stronger film were it not padded with the dull reminiscences and speculation of the settlers’ descendants. It is profusely illustrated with photographs and vintage home movies, and augmented by excerpts from diaries and journals read by actors assuming the voices of Ritter (Thomas Kretschmann), Strauch (Cate Blanchett), Heinz (Sebastian Koch), Margret (Diane Kruger) and the Baroness (Connie Nielsen). The weirdest scene is a one-reel home movie of the Baroness and Robert preening before the camera.
Romanticized train tracks, a journal-like voice-over and the lazy pace of a New Jersey backwater are all part of the effort to cast a spell in “Indigo Children,” from the writer-director Eric Chaney.

Seemingly oblivious to scrutiny, his subjects interact with an easy naturalism as commonplace events (the birth of a baby; the death of a deer) unfold in movie-long arcs. Yet there’s a stillness to the filmmaking, coupled with Saunder Jurriaans and Danny Bensi’s truly lovely original score, that lends specific shots — toddlers bundled up like pastel Ewoks on a snowdrift, or a bakery window glowing like a still life in a gallery — a near-heartbreaking melancholy. “Northern Light” contains more than one competition, but what it’s really about is the difference between trying to win and trying not to lose.

Philip, as this scene and the title suggest, isn’t one for listening, especially to people he knows. “Listen Up Philip” is partly about his agonies both as a writer and as a human being, the two seeming — at least for him — sometimes mutually exclusive. To an extent it’s a portrait of the artist as an insufferable jerk, but, more interestingly, it’s one that opens and expands beyond that classic framework to show the life usually seen milling about in the background. Much of the story involves Philip, but it makes generous room for the women he knows, specifically his girlfriend, Ashley Kane (a brilliant Elisabeth Moss), a photographer finding increasing success. The story opens with the couple on the verge of a crisis that’s emerged as her attention has shifted from Philip to her own art.

Doug’s wife, Kara (Michelle Monaghan), is a voracious go-getter who runs a spinning class and organizes the local Tour de Woodbury, a bike race named for the generic small town where they live. She always comes in first. The couple have a pudgy 12-year-old son, Ethan (Harrison Holzer), who is obsessed with ninja warfare and expresses his rebellion by depositing samples of his poop around school. The faculty is not amused, and the Varneys are summoned to a parent-teacher conference.
For most of us, the mechanics of 3-D printers are as mystifying as the movements of galaxies — a knowledge gap that the documentary “Print the Legend” does absolutely nothing to address.

In the case of Henrik (Henrik Rafaelsen), 35 going on 21, the cave of adolescence is his refuge from several scary developments. Overwhelmed by a starter home, a new job and the prospect of imminent fatherhood, Henrik retreats to the locker room, where his infantile buddies snap towels at one another’s bare backsides. When that entertainment pales, he heads for his childhood home and a mother waiting to pamper him with comfort food and comfy slippers.

The earnest naïveté borders at times on the unintentionally comic. Ms. Bessis, the publicity material says, was 21 when the film was made. Yes, some 21-year-olds create enduring art. Many others have a camera or tape recorder or canvas but little insight to put into it.

Updating “RoboCop” was always going to be tough, if for no other reason than the original’s irony, and its future-shock visions have become today’s reality, from the downfall of Detroit to the embrace of privatization, the use of high-tech artificial limbs and the triumph of propaganda over public discourse. Radically unsentimental, the first film had a gleeful apocalyptic quality that made it feel like a feature-length version of the end of “Dr. Strangelove,” in which Slim Pickens hoots his way to doomsday. The new “RoboCop” has a star in the making with Mr. Kinnaman, an intensely sympathetic actor best known for the AMC series “The Killing,” and it also features a handful of excellent side players, including Gary Oldman, Michael Keaton and Jennifer Ehle. All that’s really missing here is a point of view.
“Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A master class on the uses of human intestines, most creatively as a method of siphoning gas.

“Trailer Park Boys,” the Canadian mockumentary franchise (which includes films and a television series), features John Paul Tremblay, Robb Wells and Mike Smith. The premise of “Swearnet” is that they are trying to escape those personas and develop new projects. After a less than productive meeting with some network executives who find them too vile for prime time, they decide to start their own Internet operation where they can curse as much as they want, which is a lot.
For all its enthusiastic vulgarity and truly terrible punk rock, “We Are Mari Pepa” is a gently endearing portrait of four amiable Mexican teenagers feeling their way toward adulthood.

The three would-be eco-terrorists are troubled by smaller matters as well, notably the sexual tension, already present between Josh and Dena, that pulls tighter once they arrive at Harmon’s place. The three main performances are flawless; you get a clear sense of each character’s personality, including each one’s capacity to be unpredictable.

Still, Orlando is part of a vivid tableau of early-20th-century urban popular culture, a milieu that provides “The Immigrant” with its setting and its inspiration. The tenor Enrico Caruso performs for the Ellis Island detainees before Orlando’s magic act, and the Bandit’s Roost, the Lower East Side nightclub where Bruno’s “doves” shed their clothes, is a hive of vaudevillian variety, home to strippers, comedians and musicians. It is hard to disentangle art from sleaze, much as, with Bruno, you can’t quite separate the lost boy from the scoundrel.

“Stranger by the Lake” is seductive and fascinating, but it is also a bit trapped in its own conceit, and in its carefully maintained emotional detachment. The persistence of Franck’s interest in Michel — which begins to resemble love — at times feels arbitrary and baffling, the result of a narrative experiment rather than the exploration of a plausible motive. Michel himself remains permanently inscrutable: scary but not haunting. And the movie, which might have been provocatively terrifying, settles for being memorably strange.
“Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for scenes of intense violence, sexual content and strong language.
1 hour 25 minutes; not rated

First, however, we must spend a chunk of the film watching clips of Mr. Cameron’s cinematic triumphs and re-enactments of his science geek childhood. Test dives, system failures and team meetings are chronicled in unnecessary 3-D, with shockingly few visual thrills or scientific explanations. Where are the biologists rhapsodizing over the 68 new species (according to the end credits) discovered during the expedition? Where are the geologists elaborating on the insight it offered into seismic activity? On the film’s website, that’s where.

A Los Angeles parking meter attendant, Michael Harris (the motor-mouthed Ryan Hansen) lives to issue tickets. Michael speaks in messaging abbreviations (he actually says “bee-tee-dubs”) and takes unseemly glee in using Facebook to make fun of the ostensible losers he fines.

Amir Ramses, the 34-year-old director of “Jews of Egypt,” says in publicity notes for his documentary that “the contradiction between modern intolerant Egypt and cosmopolitan Egypt in the first half of the 20th century” led him to focus on the period from 1949 to 1956, when many Egyptian Jews left or were forced out of the country. The film consists of archival footage and interviews, primarily with people who remember those turbulent years.

They execute a fair number of estimable moves in “Interior. Leather Bar.,” a sly conceptual coup d’art and a deeply sincere exploration of masculinity and its discontents, with a little hot sex thrown in. The movie’s ostensible point of departure is 40 minutes of graphic footage of S-and-M that the director William Friedkin was forced to edit out of “Cruising,” his 1980 thriller with Al Pacino, to avoid an X rating. Inspired by what they rather cryptically term the mythology of “Cruising,” Mr. Franco and Mr. Mathews have set out to reimagine this excised material.
“Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Nudity and lots of scare-induced cursing.
Directed by Leanne Pooley

“Ivory Tower,” a documentary about soaring costs and other problems confronting higher education, can’t seem to decide what points it wants to make and ends up making none. Parts of it seem like free advertising for the institutions it visits, which include Harvard, Arizona State University and experimental institutions like Deep Springs College. Other parts sound the already familiar lament that students come out of college with crushing debts and no prospects for the kinds of jobs that would enable them to pay off those debts. There are suggestions that colleges do a poor job of actually educating students, and that the cost issue is a result of bloated administrative salaries and a rush to build showpiece campuses.
Opens on Friday

The identity of the Intruders is what keeps “The One I Love” humming along until the inadequate, muddled finish, and to name them would be like popping a balloon: the air and the fun would both disappear. So Mr. McDowell manages and massages the mystery, even while he forgets to do much with the camera except periodically have it chase after someone. He can be frustratingly inattentive to the visual possibilities offered by the story, despite some physical bits of business and all the doors that Sophie and Ethan open and shut, emblems perhaps of their minds. There’s a touch of screwball to the setup, and at times, the movie seems on the verge of becoming a fresh contemporary gloss on what the philosopher Stanley Cavell calls the comedy of remarriage.

Dim in wits and lighting, “The Possession of Michael King” strains our eyes, spits on our intelligence and saps our generosity of spirit. Relatively untaxed, however, is the part of the brain that processes new experiences: There’s scarcely a shot or an idea in this first feature from David Jung that we haven’t seen many times before.

Until it disintegrates in an explosion of sentimentality, “Trust Me” qualifies for what could be called “The Day of the Locust” award. That imaginary honor, named for the Nathanael West novel, would be bestowed on the year’s nastiest, most stomach-turning movie about no-holds-barred Hollywood wheeling and dealing. Such films are usually box office poison, but they still are made, perhaps because they give their creators a chance to vent.

“Birds are my muses, and I strive to be a true watcher,” he says, referring to people who seek a transcendent connection between human and bird souls. But he acknowledges that his preference for birding over everything else has destroyed his home life. “I’m 63 years old, and I have one leg and no driver’s license,” he says. “Please don’t confuse me with a role model.”

Had “Devil’s Knot” dared to spin out a bizarre conspiracy theory, the way Oliver Stone’s “JFK” did, it probably would have been more compelling than this workmanlike recapitulation of the so-called West Memphis Three case. Because the movie, based on a book by Mara Leveritt, stays within the facts, its reticence reinforces the notion that truth is stranger than fiction. The real-life characters, as shown in the documentaries, are far more colorful and quirky than they appear in these well-acted but comparatively safe performances.

But even though the scale of this film — the size of its budget and the breadth of its themes — is larger than anything this director has attempted before, “Noah” is less an epic than a horror movie. There are some big, noisy battle scenes and some whiz-bang computer-generated images, but the dominant moods are claustrophobia and incipient panic. The most potent special effects are Mr. Crowe’s eyes and the swelling, discordant strains of Clint Mansell’s score. Once the waters have covered the earth and the ark is afloat, a clammy fear sets in, for both the audience and the members of Noah’s family: We’re stuck on a boat full of snakes, rats and insects, and Dad’s gone crazy.

The droning of insects is incessant, and every crack of a twig or screech of a monkey is cause for alarm. When he encounters another soldier, the initially tense confrontation gives way to a sense of relief: The fighter (Mo Tzu-yi) is Chinese. There’s comfort in the buddy system, no matter the language barrier.

The settlers may have hoped to forsake the outside world, but the European newspapers and magazines of the day kept tabs on them as best they could and published mostly fanciful stories. The film reconstructs a social history of Floreana from the arrival of Ritter and Strauch until 1934, when this island of fractious pioneers disintegrated after a drought and two possible murders.

“We Are the Best!” is honest in just that way. It is also fun, which may come as something of a relief to those who endured Mr. Moodysson’s recent explorations — some of them quite powerful (“Lilya 4-Ever”), some muddled and misguided (“Mammoth”) — of the world’s misery and injustice. Life is not entirely fair to Bobo and Klara, but their protest is a source (and a form) of exultation. When Bobo is feeling blue, Klara cheers her up by reminding her that she’s part of “the greatest band in the world.” No argument here.

Held together with few words and only the loosest of narratives, this insightful first feature from Eliza Hittman unspools mostly in sensual (but never salacious) close-ups and dreamy tracking shots. Using a soft light that makes skin tones sing, Sean Porter photographs the mainly young cast with an easy intimacy that highlights his director’s highly intuitive points. Collaborating seamlessly, the filmmakers remind us of the dangers of teenage desire and — especially when seasoned with the rap music Sammy enjoys — the vast gulf between male and female notions of romantic connection.

Mr. Cooper edits like a pedagogue, at times bluntly hammering his ideas, as in a sequence in which he toggles between one of Rodney’s bloody fights and Russell hunting a deer with his Uncle Red (Sam Shepard). Like the editing, Mr. Shepard’s casting is predictable, almost formulaic, and it underscores Mr. Cooper’s weaknesses as a filmmaker. There’s nothing wrong with Mr. Shepard as a performer here and most anywhere, and there’s often a lot that’s right. He’s fun to look at, for starters — you could spend hours tooling along the byways etched into his elegantly weathered face — but too many directors use him as simplistic shorthand for American masculine decency, like the last of the Mohicans if the Mohicans were old white dudes, which is perhaps, finally, Mr. Cooper’s point.

The only problem with that Times Square hallucination, with its spinning camera and swirling color, is that it feels too short, which is true of the movie over all, despite the dragginess brought on by its thin plot, clichés and bouts of overfamiliarity. And as you listen to the gorgeous “Hush Child (Get You Through This Silent Night)” or a blow-the-roof-off version of Stevie Wonder’s “As” — the executive music producer is Raphael Saadiq — it becomes increasingly clear that the entire movie probably should have been sung. Because, at her best in “Black Nativity,” Ms. Lemmons, who also helped write some songs, has found a way to exalt the past while remaining rooted in the present in a movie that flirts with nonrealist theatricality even as it barrels right toward old-fashioned cornball entertainment.

The stories of these three and others are narrated by the characters themselves, who speak directly to the camera in a casual round-robin style with minimal self-dramatization. Their monologues are interspersed with scenes from their lives.

Another day, another cabin in the woods and another hairy monster with titanic tootsies. It was only a few months ago that Bobcat Goldthwait’s “Willow Creek” sent a pair of innocents into the shrubbery on a found-footage hunt for Bigfoot. Now “Exists,” with its five young-and-dumb vacationers, offers Sasquatch a more substantial meal.

If “The Green Prince” sustains the tension of a well-executed thriller, it is achieved at the cost of a dispassionate objectivity. There are no outside voices to augment a film that becomes the increasingly sentimental story of a boundary-breaching friendship. In one emotional moment, Mr. Yousef recalls cooking a last supper with his father while knowing that they are both about to be arrested.
Opens on Friday.
In this movie? Ha.

If some of the facts that mingle seamlessly with the fiction in “The German Doctor” are familiar, it’s no wonder. The story of Josef Mengele, the Nazi doctor known as the Angel of Death, has been told so often and in such attenuated and mythologizing fashion that it has become part of our collective pop consciousness. Most famously, there’s “The Boys From Brazil,” the 1976 Ira Levin novel about old Nazis conspiring in South America that was turned into a 1978 thriller with Gregory Peck (!) as Mengele, and Laurence Olivier as a Nazi hunter. Olivier was on the other side in John Schlesinger’s 1976 film version of “Marathon Man,” playing a former Auschwitz dentist, called the White Angel, whose way with a drill set back dentistry about as much as “Psycho” did showering.

Outspoken nonbelievers like Sarah Silverman and Ricky Gervais pop up occasionally to enliven this monotonous travelogue. But every time we’re in danger of becoming immersed in either scientist’s smoothly honed rebuttals of religion, we’re hustled along to the next fan forum on the chords of a bizarrely rock-centric soundtrack. Rather than allow Mr. Dawkins to expand, say, on his optimistic view that religion is now “a wounded animal,” Mr. Holwerda has constructed a film that merely resembles a promotional tour for Mr. Krauss’s latest book.

The articulate screenplay, by Mr. Meyer and Luke Matheny, sustains a steady tension. The friends’ trip takes place in the stolen car of David’s older cousin, and it comes on the eve of his father’s marriage to the woman who cared for his ailing mother until her death a year and a half earlier. The father (James Le Gros) and son have never processed their grief or discussed the imminent marriage, which David is too shy to say he deeply resents, even though he agreed to be the best man.

Jean-Luc Godard, who will soon celebrate his 84th birthday, holds a special place in the pantheon of modern cinema. He is an imp who is venerated as a deity, a Rorschach test, a lightning rod, a fighting word. His name seems to divide the world into skeptics and worshipers, with not much middle ground. Analogous figures can be found in other zones of 20th-century art: Andy Warhol, Bob Dylan, Ezra Pound. They have their singularity in common. They also tend to confound easy distinctions between genius and trickery, and to marshal armies of exegetes in what may be the futile enterprise of figuring out what they mean.

Hours before a six-month research mission on Mars is about to end, the eight exhausted crew members of Tantalus Base, demoralized after having made no significant discoveries, are counting the moments until their voyage home. Everything changes when an ambitious officer (Goran Kostic) finds fossilized evidence of life during a lab test and leaves the base with another crew member to investigate. After taking a bacterial sample from the soil, they find themselves infected and transforming into zombies on the rampage.
“The Expendables 3” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for action stars going about their business.
“People give jobs to their friends and relatives,” one woman with a resigned expression reports.
1 hour 40 minutes; not rated

On the movie’s terms, he’s super cool — one adversary refrains from killing him because he’s “a fantastic guy.” And Mr. Dhulia wants us to believe in Raja’s honesty, especially in contrast to the on-the-take politicians and police.

The film’s storytelling is straightforward, almost standard-issue, but the story itself is compelling, as is the testimony of devotees. It’s not surprising to see interviews with Ravi Shankar, Deepak Chopra and George Harrison (who died in 2001). It’s a bit more so to hear contemporary scientists marvel at Yogananda’s understanding of neuroplasticity decades before Western science considered it.

That’s because when they meet at their offspring’s graduation, it’s hate at first sight. The sotto voce insults fly: Punjabis have money but no culture; Tamils are too dark-skinned. These twains cannot meet.

As with every new chapter in such series, introductions must be made in “The Winter Soldier” so that nonenthusiasts can meet the team members and grasp their place in this cosmos. Here, these include Bucky Barnes (a good Sebastian Stan), Natasha Romanoff a.k.a. Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) and Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson), who run S.H.I.E.L.D., the spy agency that here gives the movie its topical gloss. Kevin Feige, who runs Marvel Studios, has said that the Russos were hired as directors “because they loved our explanation that we really want to make a ’70s political thriller masquerading as a big superhero movie.” That’s the idea anyway, which explains why Robert Redford, the star of ’70 paranoid classics like “Three Days of the Condor,” plays Alexander Pierce, a S.H.I.E.L.D. official.

Many of those collaborators are now lost to AIDS. But Ms. Goldin, who turns 61 in September, touches only lightly on the emotional and physical bruises that give so much of her work its raw potency. Leaving the more painful snapshots to tell their own story, she matches the film’s warm, just-before-sunset glow — even the indoor scenes have a coppery sheen — with smoky musings on religion, self-injury and falling in love with beautiful, sometimes gay men. Listening silently and invisibly, Ms. Lidl provides a respectful, intimate frame for these confidences: cherished memories of a time when friend, lover and subject were often one and the same.

Are you dating or just hooking up? According to Jason (Zac Efron), who narrates “That Awkward Moment,” a vile, witless sex comedy set in contemporary Manhattan, the dreaded word that signals danger to a smug, self-imagined stud is a post-coital “So?” Spoken by a woman wondering if their casual relationship will proceed to the next level — dating — it is a clear warning that the time has come to run for the hills.

Spanning ethnicities and incomes — without drawing conclusions based on either — Ms. Ben-Ari simply observes the nursing journeys of five new mothers in New York City. All are candid, hopeful and a little hesitant, bravely allowing the camera access to intimate moments and difficult decisions. Variously confronting sexual and financial worries, lack of maternity leave and performance anxiety, the women transform a seemingly simple act of mothering into a complex diary of daily challenges.

Instead, the film spends a lot of time on a history of the school, which was founded in 1868, and on the monks’ version of what ails young people in poor neighborhoods, all of it obvious and familiar: broken homes, abuse, lack of role models, pressure to join gangs. The fragments of classroom work and extracurricular life that we do see look commendable enough, but the practicalities of translating the success of St. Benedict’s to an entire city are left unexplored.

Written by Misan Sagay, “Belle” tracks its heroine’s dawning awareness of both her own social, political and legal position and that of the black slaves who, initially, exist for her only as abstractions. Her education comes through her uncle, the Lord Chief Justice, who has to decide on a horribly real case involving the Zong slave ship, as well as from an amusingly dashing suitor, John Davinier (Sam Reid). The movie plays with the historical record for dramatic effect, as is often the case when the past is disinterred for entertainment, and its realism at times groans under the weight of too many passionate speeches. Yet the weave of the personal and the political finally proves as irresistible as it is moving, partly because it has been drawn from extraordinary life.

Having a recognizable face does have the effect of, somewhat awkwardly, underlining the crushing anonymity of the journey’s many casualties. It’s hard to tell how much this was intended by the filmmakers. (The movie was written by Mark Monroe and directed by Marc Silver.) In any case, it also amounts to a gruesome body swap: Mr. García Bernal’s pristine traveler following the route of the sneaker-wearing corpse shown at the beginning, bloated and digitally blurred.

Instead, this race-to-the-top tale of warring companies and competing philosophies, crammed with geek-speak and comfy sweaters, unfolds as a case study on start-up dreams versus marketplace realities. Focusing on strategic players, the directors, Luis Lopez and J. Clay Tweel, cleverly position them as easily distinguishable archetypes: the rebel, the idealist and the charismatic visionary. They may all share brain power and complexions the color of mashed potatoes — and be photographed with less flair than the average mug shot — but at least we can tell them apart.

It’s not to be, but Mr. Goldthwait gives us lovely, buttery daylight scenes, nicely relaxed leads and dialogue that pays attention to fluctuating gender dynamics. He also engineers a static, almost wordless 19-minute shot inside a tent that generates more tension than many horror directors achieve with a swarm of foley artists and a healthier budget. This canny exploitation of the power of silence is unnerving; that it should come from one of our most aggressively vocal performers is an unexpected treat.

“What you don’t dare imagine, we dare to do” is the motto of the dream team known as “Personal Tailor,” a fantasy fabrication service (led by Ge You and Bai Baihe) that provides wealthy clients with a taste of the lives they have always wanted. No request is too outlandish (the “Custom Martyrdom Package” will furnish you with a simulated Nazi interrogation, hunger strike optional) or too elaborate, even if the outcomes are not always as planned.

The film’s songs, imperfectly staged, feel pitched to younger tots, uneasily bridging Broadway and a children’s television show. All in all, the beloved kingdom of Oz is not well served, though there’s just enough detectable affection to keep it from feeling like a pure cashing-in.

One morning, a fellow named Ig Perrish, played with overcaffeinated intensity by Daniel Radcliffe, wakes up to discover that a pair of horns have sprouted around his hairline. Like poor Gregor Samsa in Kafka’s “The Metamorphosis,” Ig never really understands why this transformation has taken place, but if the causes are mysterious, the effects are truly bizarre.
“Angels in Stardust” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for sporadic sexual references.

The full title of the new documentary by Maria Iliou, “From Both Sides of the Aegean: Expulsion and Exchange of Populations, Turkey-Greece: 1922-1924,” is quite a mouthful. It not only describes the subject but also gives a sense of the film’s dry, dense and sometimes convoluted style of exploring this otherwise fascinating subject.

“Lilting” is about connections made and missed, and it opens with Kai’s visiting his mother at the old-age home where he has parked her in London. Her room is small and drab, its institutional dinginess matched by the putty-looking cinematography and relieved only by a few knickknacks and the indifferent blue of cut hydrangeas. Kai asks if she’d like to visit him, and then warms her up a bit by asking her to cook for him while she’s there. The exchange is meant to convey the ordinary intimacy shared by mother and son but also to hint at an underlying tension — you later learn that Kai had something he wanted to say to Junn — but the actors are so stiff and the sound work so devoid of texture that the exchange lacks conviction.
“Hours” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for violence, drug references and tense situations.

No one is a villain in this aggressively feel-good movie. On the evening Ramsey appears, Carl is pressured by the restaurant’s owner (Mr. Hoffman) not to follow his instincts and experiment but to serve the same-old, same-old dishes; he is predictably pilloried on Ramsey’s blog. Making matters infinitely worse, Carl, who is naïve about social media, is brought up short when his venomous response to the review goes viral and is followed by an angry face-to-face encounter with Ramsey that is captured on diners’ smartphones.

Amy’s voice-overs disrupt the movie’s inaugural seriousness. In flashbacks introduced by her scribbling in her diary, she reveals that she’s the inspiration for a beloved and profitable book series about a girl, Amazing Amy, created by her psychologist parents, Rand and Marybeth (David Clennon and Lisa Banes). Like Hannibal Lecter (a psychiatrist), Amy’s parents have profited from messing around in other people’s heads. (Your parents plagiarized your childhood, Nick says with husbandly commiseration.) They’re cartoons, but then, so is Amy, whose narration Ms. Pike delivers in an affectedly hushed, conspiratorial voice that’s so arch that you can picture Amy’s lips curling at the edges. Mr. Fincher doesn’t show you her sneer; he doesn’t have to. It imbues every word she says, instantly casting her as an unreliable narrator.

That also sounds like a business philosophy that the old Hollywood chieftains could have gotten behind, and it may well be that Harvey Weinstein or a compatriot once said something like it when discussing the art and eroticism of movie marketing. I jest, surely. Whatever the case, the movie business was also clearly percolating in Mr. Folman’s brain alongside Mr. Lem’s novel, though, again, it takes a while for these two parts to connect. Obvious-adverse, Mr. Folman opens his movie by dropping you into the flow midstream and then lets you bob along as Ms. Wright, as Robin, weeps and Harvey Keitel, as Al, sits across from her, calling out, “Robin, Robin” and berating her for “lousy choices.” Is he talking about Robin or Ms. Wright? Her role in “The Crossing Guard” or Mr. Penn?

What is perhaps hardest to imagine, for those of us who did not experience Eastern Bloc Communism firsthand, is the way its cruelty and absurdity were woven into the fabric of everyday life. “Burning Bush,” taking place during a period of what the authorities referred to as “normalization,” depicts part of the process of weaving. What is especially striking is how many of the characters affected by Palach’s death and the government’s panicked response to it insist on behaving as if they live in a society dedicated to reason and the rule of law.

Ms. Halpern (who has made fiction films, including “Your Name Here,” featuring Mr. Foulkes) and Mr. Quilty face a common pitfall: a reluctance to rein in a personality. Maybe it arises from a belief in the authenticity of an unmediated voice, or maybe just from growing accustomed to his routine. But Mr. Foulkes overwhelms this documentary, which buys into his one-man band a little too much.
ICEMAN
“The Rover” is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian). Grisly violence and foul language.

It seems axiomatic that the superhero costume is more important than the actor filling it, and that’s true to an extent, although perhaps only for comic-book die-hards and movie executives. For the rest of us, talent matters, as demonstrated by the chasm separating the “Dark Knight” films and failed adaptations like “Green Lantern.” Kirsten Dunst’s wistful turn as Mary Jane in Mr. Raimi’s trilogy did much to humanize the series, and helped put a personal touch on an industrial product. As Gwen, Peter’s other historically romantic foil, Ms. Stone performs much the same duty in Mr. Webb’s movies, as she effortlessly charms Peter (and you) and brings him to tears. In the comic book, both women have played a part in Peter’s life, but apparently that’s more than the franchise’s male screenwriters and directors could handle. So, with Mary Jane nowhere in sight, it’s just Gwen and Peter, dewy lovers discovering each other between spasms of mostly bloodless violence. Mr. Webb has some fun with the image of Spider-Man swinging through the urban canyons, and there are moments — as when the image freezes on the tucked, airborne Spider-Man, ready to spring into action like an Olympian — in which the movie taps into the giddy freedom and near-unboundedness that the character’s physical transformation has brought him. Special effects have become so persuasive that it now looks as if there were a real person flying through the air, rather than computer-generated pixels. That said, somebody needs to work on that sticky pale fluid that shoots from Spidey’s wrists and that at times looks distinctly X-rated.
1 hour 38 minutes; not rated

Mr. Ollivier’s fans include Pik Botha, South Africa’s foreign minister under apartheid; Chester Crocker, a Reagan administration official who pressed a “constructive engagement” policy; even Winnie Mandela. No one person is responsible for the triumph of immense political movements. But “Plot for Peace” demonstrates the truth that an Ollivier admirer notes: “Africa is a place where a single individual can still have a great effect.”

With one especially elegant shot of worshipers crisscrossing bridges, Mr. Nalin demonstrates his ability to conjure some of the essence of this spiritual journey. But the organic nature and hard-to-fathom scale of Kumbh Mela demand a more systematic strategy.

The specter of Auschwitz hovers over the film. The subject comes up early — in a fight between Jean-Marie and his father, who can’t reconcile himself to his son’s faith — and returns again and again. Jean-Marie visits the camp but finds he can recite neither the Lord’s Prayer nor Kaddish, the Jewish prayer for the dead, for his mother.

Theirs is a match made in children’s storybooks and other utopias. Ernest proves far nicer than his growl, yet is appealingly naughty. He Dumpster-dives, for one, but then he’s also a bohemian with empty pockets, a lopsided grin and a love of music and play. Celestine is artistic, too — they’re European, after all — and also as responsible as she is kind. Her gentleness extends to her wide smiles, which, along with her shortened, rounded snout, hint of fur and muted dove-gray coat, make her look rather less rodentlike than she does in the books (where, frankly, she looks a bit like a rat). This softening emphasizes her touching vulnerability, as does her changeable size: Sometimes, as when she’s weeping in Ernest’s arms, she can look terribly small. Some of us, it turns out, are mice, so it’s good that some of us are bears.
Much more interesting are Surly’s mute best friend, Buddy, a dimwitted but loyal rat, and Precious, a kooky pug whose androgynous voice is not immediately recognizable as Maya Rudolph’s.

You might think a psychiatrist would know the existing literature, but “Hector,” directed by Peter Chelsom, prefers self-help platitudes to substance. A banker (Stellan Skarsgard) introduces Hector to the pleasures of Shanghai. Hector meets with monks (and Skypes!) in the Himalayas. He assists an old school friend (Barry Atsma) with medical-mission work in Africa, where he also dispenses advice to a drug kingpin (Jean Reno) and — in the film’s glibbest episode of cultural tourism — is kidnapped and held for ransom.

Brown’s childhood and youth are depicted in larger-than-life, cartoonlike sequences. The opening moments show an exaggerated high-speed police chase that ends with Brown’s arrest (the first of many). As he arrives in Vietnam in 1968 to entertain the troops, his plane is nearly blown out of the sky in a hail of thunderous explosions. A sequence with Brown and the Famous Flames outfitted in collegiate garb for a Frankie Avalon movie is played for satire. Only one incident, late in Brown’s career, in which he punches one of his wives, stands for the many instances of his spousal abuse.

While it is unlikely that Mr. Rumsfeld would describe himself as a postmodernist, he does seem to be invested in the obscurity of truth and the indeterminacy of meaning, and to believe that what we know is constructed by language rather than reflected in it. An important figure in a political faction famously committed to creating its own reality, he patiently explains the role that “imagination” plays in world affairs. Mr. Morris, an ardent old-school positivist, suggests the word “intelligence” as a substitute.

If the bloopers over the end credits are any guide, Mr. Beers appears to have fed his actors certain one-liners on the spot. That suggests that some of the film’s problems could have been avoided. But this is still a movie about ejaculation-enabled time warps.

The couple issue one dare after another to the two friends — punch a bouncer; spank a stripper — and pay off in wads of cash, the amounts increasing with the riskiness or distastefulness of the dare. Soon the lure of money has turned Craig and Vince against each other as they vie for the cash, and the dares become darker and bloodier.
Directed by Peter Mettler

In the age of online interconnectivity, stories about strangers stranded in snowstorms make little sense. Nevertheless, in the dark comedy “Tiger Lily Road,” two women take advantage of a blizzard to wage a new battle in the war between the sexes when a guy on the lam turns up at their doorstep.

Perched precariously at the intersection of race, religion and sexual identity, “The New Black,” Yoruba Richen’s calm and nuanced exploration of African-American attitudes toward same-sex marriage, balances crude filmmaking with sophisticated insights.
Directed by Richard Wolf

Mr. Elba doesn’t look much like Mr. Mandela. He is considerably beefier. But he has the same sharp, hyper-alert gaze that acknowledges the world’s horrors while looking above and beyond toward a humanitarian ideal. He also captures Mr. Mandela’s distinctive accent with an uncanny accuracy. Mr. Elba is completely convincing as a natural leader with a ferocious drive. He makes you feel the almost unimaginable personal price Mr. Mandela paid by spending 27 years in prison, separated from his family and the anti-apartheid movement on an island off Cape Town. His lowest moment comes when he is forbidden to leave the island to bury his eldest son.

Within its formulaic outlines, “Kelly & Cal” largely avoids seeming pat and contrived. It goes out of its way to flesh out subsidiary characters, like Cal’s caring mother (Margaret Colin), whom he disparages behind her back, and Kelly’s strait-laced mother-in-law (Cybill Shepherd), who pressures her into a cosmetic makeover after she dies her hair blue. The film parallels Kelly’s difficulty in bonding with her young son and Cal’s reflexive hostility toward his mother.
Directed by Mark Raso

After a somewhat tense opening chase involving a lot of girders, much of the film is rather shakily assembled (with lens flare effects passed off as flourishes). A couple of reasonably sketchy characters surface — a greedy witness and her friend, a business dude playing it fast and loose — but there’s not enough here for even an imported action hero to work with.

The young Dawson (Luke Bracey) and Amanda (Liana Liberato) look and act nothing like their grown-up selves. When they meet again, she is unhappily married, with a teenage son, and he has been working on an oil rig after serving time for an accidental shooting. What brings him home is the reading of a will after the death of his avuncular mentor and guardian angel, Tuck (Gerald McRaney), the movie’s omniscient commentator.

The fate of the missing souls on HBO’s “The Leftovers” remains a tantalizing mystery, but the location of the disappeared in “Left Behind” — an inept remake of Vic Sarin’s 2001 dud of the same title — is soon solved. Not even an act of God can flummox Nicolas Cage for long.

Narrated by Sigourney Weaver (and having precisely nothing to do with the Beatles), the movie focuses on migrant families who have crossed from Myanmar into Thailand, where they live without documents and state services. The police can fine them for not having papers. The children are at risk of kidnapping and trafficking.

The fugitive, whose picture is flashed on television, pressures Adele into taking him home, where he can hide out. Once there, he ties her up, then cooks a batch of chili, which he spoon-feeds her like a baby as she gazes up at him beseechingly. The hours pass, and Adele slowly melts, resting her head on Frank’s shoulder while Henry observes, spellbound.
“Enemies Closer” is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian) for gruesome deaths and cursing.
Directed by Geoff Marslett

Ms. Foner is also the mother of Maggie Gyllenhaal, to whom Ms. Olsen bears a striking resemblance in voice and manner. Ms. Gyllenhaal’s husband, Peter Sarsgaard, appears in an unnecessary role as Lilly’s infatuated senior co-worker on a boat where she works as a tour guide. In more ways than one, “Very Good Girls” is a family affair.
It’s all light as a feather, with Jeremy Leven, the writer and director, landing some good multinational jokes along the way.

Flipping through 180 degrees so often that it can be disorienting, “Patema Inverted,” showing violent resistance to miscegenation — and an elderly villain with an unsavory fixation on the childlike Patema — may be a little scary for small children. But the music is lovely, and the animation is soft and imaginatively detailed. Patema and Age may not know what’s upside down or right-way up, but their director is never in any doubt.

Several times, “Perfect Sisters” shifts its tone so jarringly that you’re left scratching your head. But eventually you realize that Stan Brooks, the director, might be making a point with the incongruity. If so, kudos to him for trying something different in a movie that otherwise could have seemed like an extended episode of any of the scheming-teenager shows that are all over television.
AMONG RAVENS

Cynics might describe “Labor Day” as an instructional manual on S-and-M seduction. Its first lesson is that some light bondage is necessary to show a woman who’s in charge before a man reveals his gentler side. Mr. Brolin speaks softly, but his every word has a grim, authoritarian undertone. He is handsome, with chiseled triceps, but he has a mean face.

The opening and closing scenes of Mary Fishman’s documentary “Band of Sisters” show nuns demonstrating for the rights of illegal immigrants facing deportation at a detention center in Broadview, Ill. The sisters’ persistence eventually gives them access to the center, which they had not been permitted to enter, along with the right to accompany the deportees on buses to an airport. These scenes establish the movie’s gently progressive agenda.
