Its violence is low-tech — a clothespin and a suppository feature prominently — and its look is old-school, but its message could not possibly be more momentous.
“Stalingrad” is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sometimes disturbing war violence and a sexual situation.
“Force Majeure” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some strong language and brief nudity.
“Fading Gigolo” is rated R. (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian.) Under-the-sheet romping.

“Gringo Trails” favors emotional appeals over statistics. In its most effective segment, the movie charts the expanding partygoing scene at Haad Rin, an isolated beach site in Thailand that has grown into what one reveler calls “a mid-20s summer camp.” With shots of litter lining the shore, the film suggests that the financial benefits of a tourist influx don’t help without a viable development plan.

Before leaving, Joey’s uncle (Christopher Pinkalla) introduces Chad (Will McCormack), a Boo Radley simpleton of indeterminable diagnosis. Lanky and a bit too clean-cut, Chad makes cryptic pronouncements; he tells Saul, a successful author who’s secretly a fraud, “I’ve read four books in my life, and three of them were yours.”

When we meet the principals of “The Pact 2,” they are already intimately acquainted with death: Not only does June (Camilla Luddington of “Grey’s Anatomy”) work by day as a cleaner of grisly crime scenes, but she also moonlights drawing horror comics. Her boyfriend, Daniel (Scott Michael Foster), a cop, had a father who ran a mortuary. So maybe we shouldn’t be surprised when the Judas killer (Mark Steger), a malevolent spirit, comes a-knocking for June.

Shooting in North Carolina, Ms. Janiak hides her budgetary constraints by keeping the special effects simple and her focus on the central relationship. Playing the emotional beats straight, Ms. Leslie (until recently, a regular on “Game of Thrones”) gives Bea’s transformation an icy, inhuman edge, while Mr. Treadaway conveys his predicament with credible helplessness. When your new spouse starts behaving like a stranger, would you really go rushing to the authorities?

The movie was three-quarters of the way toward completion when Hurricane Sandy hammered the Rockaways. Mr. Fleischner’s home was destroyed, and the subway closed for over a week. He had to rethink the ending.

Messy in parts and at least 15 minutes too long, “Personal Tailor” is also cunningly acted and lushly photographed (by Zhao Xiaoshi) in dazzling candy-bright colors. By the final section, however, as a wistful character apologizes to the planet for polluting its air and water, clear-cutting its forests and ravaging its grasslands, you may be a lot closer to crying than laughing.

“Fury,” which takes its title from the name painted on the barrel of the tank’s big gun, is less an epic than a series of tense and focused episodes. It’s about the grind of tactics rather than the sweep of strategy, the struggle for local objectives rather than ultimate goals. The battle scenes are staged with blunt, ground-level virtuosity, and with a welcome regard for spatial and visual coherence. When the tank needs to cross an expanse of muddy ground, you feel every jolt and swerve. And there is a lot of muddy ground to cover.

“Dragon 2” is considerably darker and more self-aware than its forerunner. Both films are speedier than the average animated blockbuster. In places, “Dragon 2” is almost too fast to keep up with, and, in other places, it’s a little too dark, at least in 3-D. The spectacle quotient has been increased exponentially, and you are keenly aware of the divisions between its adagio and allegro passages. Its thundering air-war sequences, with hordes of dragon-riding fighters swarming into battle, have the swooping, gliding kineticism of vintage newsreels of World War II dogfights.

The movie is at its best, however, when talk recedes and everything goes quiet. In the small, wordless interactions of Alex and his ailing grandmother (a wonderfully expressive Petra Iñiguez Robles), we hear the smack of innocence colliding with experience. And as she gently washes his hands and cooks his breakfast, we fear that his carefree summer will be ending all too soon.
“McCanick” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence, sexual themes and some drug dealing.

“Hard to Kill,” like its predecessor, is a gangster movie with a social conscience. It programmatically tries to humanize its characters, some of whom limply justify their criminal behavior by pointing out how hard they work to support their loved ones. Most are also aware that they have led miserable lives and feel guilty about the many ways they have failed those loved ones. They may be desperados, but, by and large, they are not the sociopaths who populate so many American Mafia movies.

“Eventually, you’ll destroy yourself,” one former company member ruefully admits. But, until then, it’s all joy and motion in this dazzled and breathless documentary by Catherine Gund, who traces Ms. Streb’s artistic journey through Haight-Ashbury in the 1970s to the warmly cluttered SoHo loft she shares with her longtime partner, the journalist Laura Flanders. Performance and rehearsal footage reveals an architect’s eye for symmetry, and an oeuvre — including one number derived from a medieval torture device — dedicated to overcoming limitations of physics and physiology.

Shortly before Nathan’s girlfriend’s new book comes out, she breaks up with him by announcing an affair with a literary agent. Still shocked, Nathan decamps from the writer-infested Brooklyn to visit his ailing, opinionated parents in Florida: Mom (Linda Lavin) is forgetful because of Alzheimer’s, and Dad (Harris Yulin, an eloquent growler) is a stroke risk.

With her woman warrior, the writer and director Claudia Myers has landed on a good, urgent, relevant theme. She augments it with some nice details (Maggie proves somewhat of a gear head) and a few scenes that express the existential reality of the soldier-mother (to get to work on time, Maggie takes Paul to day care before sunup). But Ms. Myers too often tells rather than shows, and she doesn’t have the cinematic skill set to transform her idea into a fully satisfying movie, especially at this low-budget level. The cinematography is dreary-looking; the blocking often awkward and unimaginative. The performances are hit and miss, though now and again the secondary actors, notably Mr. Livingston, pull their weight so that Ms. Monaghan doesn’t have to shoulder it alone.

“But Always” follows two friends and later lovers, Anran (Gao Yuanyuan) and Zhao Yongyuan (Nicholas Tse), as they meet in childhood in Beijing in 1982, repeatedly separate without goodbyes, reunite or fail to rendezvous in assorted torrential downpours and pine for each other at their favorite bus stop.

“2 States” is based on a novel by Chetan Bhagat, so it’s not surprising that the film has a novelistic texture and pace. But the screen demands more narrative economy than the script can muster, and that texture doesn’t carry over to the characters, though there are hints of their origins in another kind of storytelling.

Daniel, the most enthusiastically rakish of the three, exudes some mischievous energy, but his repulsive 20-something character, who resembles Elvis Presley’s doughy grandson, seems all of 15. The notion that his secret girlfriend, Chelsea (Mackenzie Davis), would put up with this oleaginous braggart for five minutes is beyond comprehension.
“Planes: Fire & Rescue” is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Disregard for forest fires and a sort-of answer to the question

As he lies dying, Evelyn, in one of those eureka moments that implies her brain is as infinite as her husband’s, initially uploads Will’s consciousness into PINN, a clever bit of business she manages with their friend Max Waters (a solid Paul Bettany), a neurobiologist. One minute Will looks like a tortured lab monkey; the next, he’s the ghost in everybody’s machine. Well, it sounds plausible or at least Mr. Pfister moves fast enough that you don’t have time to puzzle over niceties like logic.

Any more recap is pointless — such plots are rarely coherent. For a would-be skin-and-horror treat, though, “Cam2Cam” is surprisingly prudish. It doesn’t really traffic in sex; the camera mostly averts its gaze from the murders, preferring blood spatter patterns; and the acting is predictably wooden. It’s almost as if everyone just wanted a trip to Thailand. They may have enjoyed their time, but this souvenir doesn’t make anyone’s clip reel.

We first see the central character, an Australian fighter pilot (Khan Chittenden), dangling from a tree in the jungle. It is 1942, and the battle for Singapore has commenced. Now behind enemy lines, he must avoid detection by the Japanese troops who have come ashore. His provisions are meager (a compass, a map and a chocolate bar are deemed worthy of keeping), and the tropical surroundings imposing (tall grass, knee-deep mud and steam-room-level humidity).

Mr. Lafitte regards her with an undisguised lust not seen in a movie since Olivier Martinez scrutinized Diane Lane in “Unfaithful.” But Caroline never completely melts. Even in dishabille, she maintains her composure and rarely seems hot and bothered. When she realizes that she is only one in a rotating procession of Julien’s lovers, she accepts it stoically, with only a tinge of disappointment.

A long time ago, a doctor told the photographer Nan Goldin that she had the genes of an Olympic athlete. Just as well: Even while eliding the details of her colorful, adventurous past, “Nan Goldin: I Remember Your Face” contains enough throwaway references to bodily harm to make her and her admirers grateful for the gifts of biology.
Directed by Jeremy O’Keefe

Ms. Bélézy brings a sultriness and vulnerability to Fanny, but Mr. Auteuil, as César, shows less range than the towering Raimu, who turned that part — a bar owner and Marius’s father — into a wry observer of life’s foibles. Mr. Auteuil rushes his lines at what should be the series’s emotional peak: César explaining to a returning Marius that love is what adds weight to a child.
Proceeding in a tone of unrelieved misery, “Coldwater” is a punishing, predictable drama that’s almost rescued by strong acting and good intentions.

Most male directors would think twice before wading into a comedy about menopause, but not Henry Jaglom. For his 19th film, “The M Word,” this warmly humane and unfailingly indulgent observer of women and their distractions — as celebrated in “Babyfever” (1994) and “Going Shopping” (2005) — proves as comfortable with hot flashes as with cooling desire.

It’s a tough choice, but if I had to pick the most Wes Anderson moment in “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” it would be the part when inmates escape from a prison using tiny sledgehammers and pickaxes that have been smuggled past the guards inside fancy frosted pastries. This may, come to think of it, be the most Wes Anderson thing ever, the very quintessence of his impish, ingenious and oddly practical imagination. So much care has been lavished on the conceit and its execution that you can only smile in admiration, even if you are also rolling your eyes a little.

The resemblance between the two men is so precise that when Adam telephones Anthony’s house, Helen mistakes him for her husband. Anthony wears a beard, drives a motorcycle and favors leather jackets and sunglasses, whereas Adam is strictly a corduroy-jacket and Volvo kind of guy. He also seems a little nicer than his double, though perhaps not as much fun to be around. In any case, much of the fun in “Enemy,” which is tightly constructed and expertly shot, lies in Mr. Gyllenhaal’s playful and subtle performances. He was the best, most enigmatic part of “Prisoners,” Mr. Villeneuve’s somber thriller from last fall, and he continues to refine his quiet, watchful presence into a powerful and idiosyncratic acting style.

The jokes and sight gags fly in exhausting profusion in “The Breakup Guru,” Deng Chao and Yu Baimei’s antic, scattershot romantic comedy. Mr. Deng plays the titular fixer, Mei Yuangui, a successful specialist in terminating the relationships of celebrities and socialites through entrapment, public humiliation and other unsavory methods. (These tactics are accompanied by a lot of mugging and extreme grimacing.) Now, with three trusty helpers, Yuangui has one last job: to help a smarmy, Western-style motivational speaker and “successologist” (Liang Chao) unload his Beijing mistress, Ye Xiaochun (Yang Mi). To that end, Yuangui resolves to trick the mistress into falling for none other than himself. Somehow, for all his overemphatic mannerisms, he succeeds.
1 hour 30 minutes
“Winter’s Tale” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). A few bad words, a few moments of softly lit, metaphysically significant sex.

This sort of “Big Chill” getaway has been a staple of filmmakers from John Sayles to Joe Swanberg, yet even with a furtive pot-smoking sequence, “A Picture of You” subverts cliché. There’s enormous warmth when the hipster-ish Doug earnestly picks the wrong time to seek Kyle’s permission to propose to Jen, and a matter-of-factness to the film’s reflections on Asian-American identity. (“Did you just racially profile us?” the kids awkwardly joke whenever they’re recognized as Judy’s children.)

Traditions may vary, but Passover Seders typically end with the wish that the participants might celebrate again “next year in Jerusalem.” For eight pilgrims from the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, Conn. — average age, 91 — next year was 2011, when they toured Israel, along with nursing aides, administrators and a film crew.

That world, according to the screenwriters Alex Kurtzman, Roberto Orci and Jeff Pinkner, who share story credit with James Vanderbilt, has an almost rhythmic predictability: Spider-Man fights a villain; Peter hangs with family and friends; repeat. Fans will note canonical details, like the Ravencroft Institute for the Criminally Insane, while civilians may find themselves comparing Dane DeHaan, who plays Harry Osborn, Peter’s friendly nemesis, with James Franco, who had the role in Mr. Raimi’s trilogy. Mr. Franco was then a near-ringer for James Dean, which dovetailed with Mr. Raimi’s nods to “Rebel Without a Cause”; in this movie, Harry registers as more of a neurasthenic dandy with a dreamy, disquieting otherworldliness that can bring to mind the young David Bowie.

Andrew, Appachey and Harley are at the cusp of adolescence, starting to push back at low-rent surroundings, but still childlike. Harley trudges around, keeping up a running quirky commentary about his temper or his beloved mom, who’s in prison for tragic reasons that emerge later. Andrew is mysteriously beatific, the son of a free spirit who covers Hank Williams songs and keeps moving the family around. Less clearly drawn, Appachey has an abiding rage but, in sixth grade, none of its dignity.
Opens on Wednesday.

But Mr. Tully is less interested in climax than in reconstructing teen-movie formula through a deeply personal lens. Unfolding during a seaside vacation in Ocean City, Md., in the summer of 1985, the movie watches indulgently as 13-year-old Rad (Marcello Conte) makes a new friend (Myles Massey, a standout), squares off against two entitled bullies and gawkily woos a local hottie with a sugar addiction.

Mr. Paulson’s wife, Wendy, chimes in to help complete the picture from a perspective often overlooked in all-business documentaries, but her role as the film’s main other voice might raise an eyebrow.
Opens on Friday

While the film starts out as a seemingly fresh take on the romantic comedy, it is saddled with numerous contrivances and the clichéd trappings of the genre: big weddings, wayward souls and quick-to-judge elders. Mr. Malhotra fares well as the pragmatic Nikhil, and Ms. Chopra shines despite the material.

As two actors of opposite temperaments discuss a possible collaboration on a new production of the play, their arguments about interpretation become part of a sneaky power game in which each tries to get the better of the other. Because both want to portray the title character, Alceste, they agree to take turns if Serge Tanneur (Fabrice Luchini), the older of the two, finally says yes to the project.

Mr. Kauflin, who was born in 1986 with impaired vision, lost his eyesight completely when he was 11 and became serious about the piano around the same time. At the start of the movie, he is living in New York, trying to break into the professional jazz scene and having a hard time. We follow him through various setbacks and triumphs — a move back to his parents’ home in Virginia Beach, a tense appearance at the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Piano Competition — but the one constant is his friendship with Mr. Terry.

In this blood-splattered wasteland, neither original ideas nor acting skills flourish. A strong opening sequence shows Mark (Josh Ethier, who, as the film’s editor, splices more effectively than he emotes) disappearing into the night sky on a beam of light. Two years later, his best friend, Seth (Graham Skipper), having witnessed the abduction, is still plagued by nightmares and nosebleeds. So, when Mark returns, initially naked and fetal but gearing up for some sickening slaughter — and even more odious procreation — Seth knows it’s up to him to save mankind from the alien apocalypse.

At first, the young man seems to inspire almost universal sympathy, even as various groups try to use his death to their own advantage. Politicians and public figures allied with the still nominally independent Czech regime express concern for the state of the nation’s troubled youth, while student activists scramble to organize further protests, including a general strike. There are rumors that Palach is the first of many “living torches,” but nobody seems to know if he was really part of any coordinated group. And everyone, including ministers and police officers, is nervous about what the Soviets will do.

How do you survive the humiliation and embarrassment of being 15 and desperate to be a grown-up? Through patience and the instinctive realization that you’ve reached an awkward transition and that the worst will soon be behind you.

Her life is a familiar jumble of pleasures and frustrations, her personality a weave of moods, foibles and admirable traits. She sometimes drinks too much, smokes more than she should and hovers needily around her two grown children. She endures a dull office job and the late-night ranting of a mentally unstable neighbor, whose hairless cat finds its way into Gloria’s apartment. The more we learn about Rodolfo (Sergio Hernández), the more we might question her taste in men — a judgment confirmed during a family dinner with her ex-husband — but there is no doubting her curiosity or her confidence. She is immune to self-pity and not averse to emotional risk, as her relationship with Rodolfo demonstrates.

Historical footage of Kennedy’s speeches and other events are interspersed with interviews with historians and writers (Evan Thomas, Peter Kornbluh, Gareth Porter); former Kennedy aides (Dan Fenn and Tazewell T. Shepard Jr., who has since died); Khrushchev’s son Sergei; and Kennedy and Khrushchev’s interpreters from their Vienna summit. A brief section reviews Kennedy’s much-debated policy on Vietnam. Here we see paperwork showing that, at the time of his death, he wanted the United States advisers out.

Once in Portugal, he looks up the author; visits his severe sister, Adriana (Charlotte Rampling); and learns that Amadeu died in 1974 and that only 100 copies of his book were printed. The movie proceeds as a historical detective story that intersperses Raimund’s investigation with lengthy flashbacks to a past in which we meet the young Amadeu (Jack Huston), a charismatic member of the resistance to the dictatorship of António Salazar.

The story doesn’t politely halt as Kate’s death approaches. There are heated arguments about whether to follow her end-of-life wishes. Despite holes in the storytelling, Ms. Swank and Ms. Rossum keep it real.

However dry (thanks to the caretaker Peng Phan for smiles that leaven that tone), “Still I Strive,” by the filmmakers Adam Pfleghaar and A. Todd Smith, is a remarkable find, a tale of uplift in a too-little-seen environment.
THE HACKER WARS

The film began as a proposed adaptation of Ebert’s 2011 memoir of the same title, a self-portrait whose calm and open tone is the more remarkable for the circumstances under which it was written. Mr. James — whose own career was buoyed by his subject’s early praise for his documentary “Hoop Dreams” — first met with Ebert and his wife, Chaz, five months before Ebert’s death in April of last year. He had hoped to track Ebert as he continued to lead his determinedly productive life as critic and commentator, both in print and on the social media in which he had become a major presence.
KABBALAH ME

Scattered throughout are moments that stick out like provocations (such as an excerpt from a conservative lecture that sounds anti-Semitic), some juicy clandestine recordings and too many protest sign montages. It’s a hodgepodge that Michael Moore (whose movies Ms. Lessin and Mr. Deal have produced) and his editors might snappily dice together, but here the construction falls short.

The film culminates with a protracted blood bath in a creepy mansion. The nervous Richard; the brooding, gun-crazy Ben; and the maniacally free-spirited Jim Bob might as well be colliding bumper cars at the wildest carnival this side of Houston.

“The Overnighters” is an onion of a movie. Composed of multiple layers — more than one of which might bring tears to your eyes — this shape-shifting documentary begins as one thing and ends as quite another.

Mr. Bram’s investigations take him to a feast with long-unseen Hasidic cousins; to the Kabbalah Center in Manhattan; to a gathering at MetLife Stadium to celebrate the end of a cycle of Talmudic study; to a Purim celebration (“the Jewish Mardi Gras,” in Mr. Bram’s words) in Brooklyn; to the Western Wall in Jerusalem; and to many rabbis and scholars. He also mentions — perhaps overstates — kabbalah’s popularity with celebrities like Madonna.
Directed by Hwang Dong-hyuk
A beautiful woman leaves a bar and goes home with James Marsden. And that is just about the only thing that makes sense in “Walk of Shame.”

Mr. Teerink’s film is attuned to the intellectual implications of LeWitt’s work and to the aesthetic effects of its realization. We spend a gratifying amount of the film’s compact running time looking at witty, building-block structures in the middle of urban parks and plazas; at rooms in the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art that buzz with undulating bands of color; at walls in private houses covered in faint pencil markings.

Mili Chakravarty (Sonam Kapoor) is a high-energy, middle-class and somewhat daffy physiotherapist for a New Delhi cricket team when she is hired by an aristocratic family near Jaipur  to rehabilitate its patriarch (Aamir Raza Hussain), who’s been using a wheelchair for years. His son, Vikram (the heavy-lidded Pakistani heartthrob Fawad Afzal Khan), a shrewd businessman, is not only engaged to a woman of his economic station but is also monitored by his imperious, upper-crust mother (Ratna Pathak Shah). The brash, often clumsy Mili, in her mixed-pattern ensembles, descends on their estate like a tornado, bumping into statuary, dancing with the servants and winning hearts, especially Vikram’s.

The parental equivalent of Billy Bob Thornton’s “Bad Santa” character, Virgil had a neglectful, tough-love child-rearing style that has left his son, Boyd (Joel McHale, from “Community,” like the director, Tristram Shapeero), now grown, obsessed with preserving the illusion of Santa for his own 6-year-old. Coaxed to Wisconsin from Chicago for a rare family visit, Boyd and his wife, Luann (Lauren Graham), leave behind a stack of presents.

It’s cruel but must be said: Presented in hushed, reverent tones, “Jobriath A.D.” often comes across as mockumentary material; each ghastly career move is followed by another. Hampered by limited video of Jobriath, the film lacks a sense of him or his music. Its chief contribution is to let Jobriath’s manager, Jerry Brandt, discuss his stupefyingly dumb marketing while evading responsibility. Everything he did, he stresses, Jobriath wanted.

Odenigbo (Chiwetel Ejiofor) is a professor who speaks of how both race and nationality — unlike Nigeria’s economically fraught tribal divisions — are white man’s constructs. He loves Olanna (Thandie Newton), a modern Nigerian who has lived abroad and, as the action begins, takes a job as a lecturer. Olanna’s sister, Kainene (Anika Noni Rose), begins a fling that turns into a tumultuous relationship with an Englishman, Richard (Joseph Mawle), whose privileged perspective allows him to stand apart from the brewing strife.

Donning the requisite black-framed glasses, the boyish Pierre Niney plays the wunderkind who was tapped for creative leadership of Dior at the age of 21, ran his own trendsetting fashion house and also struggled through manic-depression. Pierre Bergé (Guillaume Gallienne) was his lover, wrangler and business partner, making for a beneficial match that would fray with the stress on both sides. The model Victoire Doutreleau (Charlotte Le Bon) also figures as a friend and mild source of intrigue, though the greater world of fashion feels sketchy.

Before long, the two are smitten, the one-night stand a foregone conclusion, all hemming and hawing aside. The true leap of faith comes afterward, when they talk seriously of leaving their lives for each other and what that would entail. No divorce is simple, but for Nora, a hard-eyed realist, it would be further complicated by the custody battle over her 4-year-old son.

The film, a music-filled follow-up to the 2011 hit “The Muppets,” lands poor Kermit in a gulag in Siberia, which is depicted just as unflatteringly as gulags in Siberia always are. Vladimir V. Putin is unlikely to be amused. But the real concern, in terms of America’s international relations, is its sly skewering of our European allies, whose work habits, vacation-taking and such are mocked relentlessly.
Still, he doesn’t mind the hostile crowds, who heckle him and then walk out, disgusted. Why should he? His money insulates him from humiliation and buys him repeat engagements.

This film — a thriller directed with Andrew Loo and set in Queens during the Chinese immigration wave of the 1980s — begins by sketching out the hungry desperation of the era, and how Chinese gangs took hold of two schoolmates, Sonny and Steven, and never let go. Senseless violence and get-ahead cynicism abound, as the story ratchets forward to track the hotheaded Steven and the slightly more prudent Sonny through Green Dragons intrigue, shootings and blowbacks. Drugs, a human trafficker and unconvincing romance fuel the mayhem.

But picturesque seascapes are about the only thing to recommend in “Summer in February,” directed by Christopher Menaul from Jonathan Smith’s choppy, underwritten adaptation of his own novel about the amorous shenanigans surrounding the famous equestrian painter Alfred James Munnings (Dominic Cooper).

But “Step Up All In,”  directed by the dancer and choreographer Trish Sie, signals a slight retreat from the bonkers, protest-themed “Step Up Revolution”  (2012), which pitted a tactically divided flash mob against a politically connected real estate developer. The new film, the fifth in the series, tackles a humbler subject: the travails of the working artist.
“They do it for ritual purpose,” a gender-violence specialist says. “To get money, to get a job.”

Those hoping to see Ms. Smith create a variation of Violet Crawley, the haughty character she plays in “Downton Abbey,” may be disappointed that Mathilde has none of the blustery camp mannerisms that make Violet, the dowager countess, a lovable über-snob. For a woman in her 90s, Mathilde has a rich, active life. She teaches English to French students in private classes and has a well-stocked wine cellar. The stress of Mathias’s circumstances drives him back to the bottle, and his outbursts suggest Falstaffian rants by a character out of Chekhov. Even when behaving like a jerk, Mr. Kline’s Mathias is unfailingly charming.

The director, Simon Brand, makes effective use of shifting video formats to distinguish different types of footage. As is customary for this genre, “Default” resorts to loopholes and odd angles to ensure continued filming. The pulsing score also distracts from the verisimilitude.

“No Tears for the Dead” is a feat of structural ingenuity. While Gon and Mogyeong speak face to face early on — he meets his target in an elevator without revealing his identity — they spend most of the movie communicating by cellphone, as the space between them fills up with potential threats, including a team of assassins from Los Angeles and possibly corrupt cops.

At the start of the movie, we learn of the Curse of the Giant Tortoise, a creature that, local legend had it, could read the dirty secrets in the minds of visitors to the islands. In a shot of a tortoise’s scaly face, it appears to wear a knowing smirk.

Once Will’s consciousness is uploaded, his voice supplants PINN’s. In its initial poetic fragmentation, the voice emanating from Evelyn’s reconfigured supercomputer sounds amusingly like Marlon Brando’s tape-recorded ramblings as Colonel Kurtz in “Apocalypse Now.” (Mr. Depp and Brando were friends.) After some throat clearing, though, Will starts to sound like himself and the movie gets its crazy on.

The camera pans restlessly, showing us steely-gray lattice views of the business district and cutting away to a big-screen television showing congressional testimony on the financial crisis from the United States. Mr. Voss speaks calmly, and not without some nostalgia, but betraying frustration with the social conformity and sacrifice of his profession. He talks around the deepest wound, an evident distance from his family because of his long hours.

Dwight (Macon Blair) isn’t your typical movie avenger, but then “Blue Ruin” — partly named for Dwight’s battered blue Pontiac — isn’t your typical revenge movie. Concealed behind a hill-country beard and shapeless clothing, Dwight is a near-silent, homeless shadow who sleeps in his car on a Delaware beach. When we first see him, he’s enjoying a bath in a stranger’s home, dismayed when the owners arrive unexpectedly. A tidy intruder, Dwight doesn’t like to leave a mess.

As he did in earlier films like “Rana’s Wedding” (2003) and “Paradise Now” (2005), a sympathetic portrait of two would-be suicide bombers, Mr. Abu-Assad, a Palestinian born in the Israeli city of Nazareth, juxtaposes the routines of everyday life in the West Bank with the brutal facts of Israeli occupation and the resistance to it.

And, just like that, with only a mad smile and the unnerving sound of drums thundering on the score, Mr. Côté completely flips “Vic + Flo” and transforms what seemed like a pleasant, seemingly predictable movie about a collection of eccentrics into a frightening tale of revenge. This isn’t, it turns out, the usual once upon a time, but a story about the unknowns that can swallow us up.

As Irving’s other better half, Ms. Adams, a virtuoso of perkiness, goes deeper here than she’s ever been allowed to. She showed an indelibly darker, more dangerous side in a supporting role in Mr. Anderson’s “Master,” playing Lady Macbeth to a cult leader; she has a lot more to do in “American Hustle.” Like Irving, Sydney is a self-invention, one containing multitudes, from the former stripper she starts off as, to the elegant British noblewoman she pretends to be for the couple’s loan scams. With her bright eyes and alabaster gleam, Ms. Adams can look like a porcelain doll, a deceptive mien that helps complicate Sydney and turns an unpredictable character into a thrillingly wild one, whose ordinary scream is the howl of a wolf.

Mr. Harris begins on a personal note, with an anecdote about his father, depicted in old snapshots as a handsome man with a distinctly melancholy, distracted air. We never learn too much about him, but we do travel back through the generations, spending a fair amount of time looking at formal and candid photos, many of them taken by the filmmaker’s maternal grandfather.

Denis Lavant, Mr. Carax’s acteur fétiche (as the French might call a favored performer) since “Boy Meets Girl,” is one of many witnesses here to the filmmaker’s collaborations and sense of an artistic search. The press-averse Mr. Carax, who has made only five features in three decades, appears, disembodied, on the soundtrack, direct and eloquent. Ms. Louise-Salomé finds telling production details, even putting the notoriously expensive “The Lovers on the Bridge” into perspective, and also sits down fellow filmmakers like Harmony Korine and Kiyoshi Kurosawa for comment.
A different breed from “Twister” (1996), “Into the Storm” raises a question with its finest shots: Would the painter J. M. W. Turner just make disaster movies today?

By her account, Ms. Payne grew up in West Virginia with an abusive father and began her decades of thievery by stealing to help her mother. The filmmakers, Matthew Pond and Kirk Marcolina, let their charming, quick-witted and resourceful subject relate her exploits, with commentary from a longtime friend of Ms. Payne’s, her daughter, a sheriff, her lawyer and, appropriately, the writer of a screenplay about her life.

In the most excruciating scene, Tomas breaks down uncontrollably in front of the children, while the disgusted Ebba tries to soothe them. Mr. Kuhnke’s Tomas is all the creepier, because even when sobbing hysterically, his display of emotion seems a half-faked, groveling play for pity.

It does not take long for Ewa, who is desperate rather than naïve, to figure out that her savior is also a predator. But Mr. Phoenix, who appeared in three of Mr. Gray’s previous films (“The Yards,” “We Own the Night” and “Two Lovers”), is a notably complicated actor, and Bruno is by no means a simple villain. There are unmistakable gothic elements in Ewa’s tale, which is to some extent a lurid fable of wronged innocence, irrational cruelty and wild coincidence set in a landscape of betrayal, brutality and corruption. But Mr. Gray’s gentle, probing camera works its way under the skin and into the souls of the characters, who turn out to be as changeable and unpredictable as their circumstances.

Kevin Costner is one of the great salesmen in American movies, a natural-born closer. He’ll look you in the eye, start in with the pitch, and the next thing you know, you almost believe that Donald Sutherland and Lyndon Johnson killed Kennedy; that if you build a ballpark in the middle of a cornfield, “they will come”; and that “Dances With Wolves” is a better picture than “Goodfellas.” Something about him — the baby blues, the slightly weak chin, the aw-shucks manner, at once aggressive and self-effacing — makes him hard to resist, even when you know you’re being conned. That’s part of the appeal.
“Road to Paloma” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex in a trailer, on stilettos and during the commission of a crime.

The talent pool for hits on operatives must be small. Despite craving his old teacher’s approval, David is assigned to tie up loose ends and kill Peter, which leads to a game of cat-and-mouse between them. They even call each other midpursuit. “I can’t believe you’ve still got the same phone number,” Peter says during a Belgrade chase.

In the second half of the film, Ms. Mock takes Ms. Hill away from that famous image of her testifying before a panel of white men and places her in a context of power as she speaks in front of rooms full of women (like the Brooklyn-based group Girls for Gender Equity). By showing this evolution, Ms. Mock demonstrates that harassment holds its power mainly in isolation.

Perhaps too obediently, Ms. Halpern and Mr. Quilty adopt the not uncommon narrative of a comeback, building up to a New York exhibition and coming down with Mr. Foulkes’s ensuing recovery period. (The film covers seven years in all and includes Dennis Hopper among its interviewees.) The idea of a work in progress is vigorously exercised before our eyes: Mr. Foulkes adjusts elements of his textured, wall-size piece “The Lost Frontier” and saws off an offending portion of his painting “The Awakening,” influenced by a past marriage.

Mr. Kinnaman, a Swedish-American actor, made his initial splash in the United States by playing a sullen police detective in the AMC series “The Killing.” And whether speaking English or Swedish, he is a star. With a slightly sinister, hooded charisma that recalls the young James Spader or Jonathan Rhys Meyers, he is a deeper actor than either and conveys a brooding secretiveness and suppressed volatility.
1 hour 15 minutes; not rated

“Free Ride,” the feature film debut of Shana Betz, who wrote the screenplay, has the benefit of being the true story of a part of her childhood and is narrated by her alter-ego, the grown-up Shell. From top to bottom, it feels authentic, and its laid-back, nonjudgmental tone evokes the easygoing world of Jimmy Buffett songs celebrating how changes in latitude bring changes in attitude. Much of the movie seems bathed in the pink-grapefruit haze of a Florida sunset.
“RoboCop” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). The movie features gun violence.

In fairness, a number of those approached by Mr. Miller either declined or were unable to appear in the movie, but the taint of bias lingers. “Dinosaur 13” may not be the best documentary, but as a scientific soap opera, it’s a doozy.
Opens on Friday.

Instead, there is a culture clash gastro-rom-com spooned out with extreme caution. The main character is Mr. Kadam’s son Hassan (Manish Dayal), a gifted and handsome cook, who supplies early voice-over narration and later exchanges smoldering glances and stolen kisses with Marguerite (Charlotte Le Bon), a sous-chef in Madame Mallory’s restaurant. She lends him classic French cookbooks, and he cross-pollinates their tried-and-true recipes with flavors and techniques from back home.
1 hour 54 minutes

Hany Abu-Assad’s new film, “Omar,” is about Israeli-Palestinian violence and also about three friends, young men who seem familiar almost as soon as we see them together. Tarek (Eyad Hourani) is the leader, Amjad (Samer Bisharat) is the joker, and Omar (Adam Bakri) is the sensitive one, handsome and athletic with the soul of a poet. He and Amjad are both in love with Tarek’s sister Nadia (Leem Lubany), but their rivalry is kept in check by their affection for each other and by strict customs governing courtship and family life.

Nailah Jefferson’s film zeros in on the small Gulf community of Pointe à la Hache, La., about an hour from New Orleans, where the oyster industry has been devastated, leaving out-of-work fishermen and their families. The movie charges that legal settlements were slowly and ineffectively distributed. (Wes Tunnell, the marine biologist who provided the victim’s compensation fund with projections on how quickly the Gulf might rebound, expresses reservations about how his report was used.) More than one person compares fighting BP, which leased the runaway well, to fighting God.
Directed by Rob Reiner
“The Bag Man” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence, sexual content and language.

“Jealousy,” Philippe Garrel’s new film, begins in tears and proceeds through seasons of romantic melancholy, unfolding on Paris streets and in Bohemian apartments filmed in lovely shades of gray. The black-and-white images (captured by the great Belgian cinematographer Willy Kurant) seem to float free of time, accompanied by the disarmingly sweet tones of Jean-Louis Aubert’s music. The main character, a young actor named Louis, is based on Mr. Garrel’s father and played by his son (also named Louis). This tale of emotional ambivalence and wayward passion seems to be happening equally in the present, in the Nouvelle Vague era of the director’s young manhood, and at any other point in the long history of Gallic love trouble.
“Need for Speed” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Car crashes and rough language.

Directed by Ben Stassen and Jérémie Degruson (and derived from a short theme park film simulating a roller coaster with haunted house effects), “Thunder” keeps the point of view at kitty height and the action at express train speed. Scurrying across attic boards and up staircases, through the engine of a wrecking-ball machine and across a busy highway, the characters have just enough personality to engage.
“Oldboy” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Blood, gore and skin.

And if acting is your thing — or at least the particular pleasure of watching first-rate screen performers ham it up in a busy genre setting — “Snowpiercer” will not disappoint. The reluctant leader of the rebels, a back-of-the-train troublemaker named Curtis, is played by Chris Evans, his clean-cut Captain America charisma obscured by scruffy facial hair and a black wool watch cap. He is a stoical, heroic presence amid the chaos, which means he has less room to be interesting than the other actors, who provide some of that chaos. They include Octavia Spencer, John Hurt and Jamie Bell as some of Curtis’s fellow insurgents, whose careful planning and simmering resentments blossom into revolt after an especially cruel provocation by the authorities. There are soldiers in riot gear, armed with clubs and guns, but for Mr. Bong evil is never anonymous. He gives it a grotesque, human face — or rather a series of faces, most memorably Tilda Swinton’s, almost unrecognizable in prosthetic teeth and oversize glasses. She serves as a kind of spokeswoman for Mr. Wilford (Ed Harris), the enigmatic engineer who is both dictator and deity in this postapocalyptic world. As the train moves in its long, winding route around the globe, teetering on the edge of both sustainability and plausibility, Curtis and his comrades undertake a long march toward the engine. They are joined by Minsu (the great shape-shifting South Korean actor Song Kang-ho), a security specialist, and his daughter, Yona (Ko Ah-sung), both addicted to an inhalant called Kronole.

She has the hoarse and soft voice of a tomboyish little girl, and she takes this association to strange extremes when she arrives at the dinner table dressed as a football player, including eye black and a helmet. When her husband yells at her to take off her costume, she shakes her head and pouts.

Abby’s already strange behavior becomes more so when she is assigned to mentor Danni (Katrina Bowden of “30 Rock”), a new nurse who begins to suspect that Abby is a psychopath. Naughtiness and nastiness ensue, with Judd Nelson and Boris Kodjoe among the men who get caught up in it.

Melanie makes one good friend, the older and more experienced Verena (Verena Lehbauer), with whom she embarks on a furtive trip to a nearby nightclub where she passes out drunk and narrowly avoids being raped. But the core of the drama focuses on Melanie’s crush on the camp doctor, a fit, gray-haired man in his 50s whom she repeatedly visits with bogus complaints of stomach cramps.
“Get On Up” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Mild sexual content, some drug use, some strong language and violent situations.

To call Bettie unflappable doesn’t mean she is unfeeling. Even when her world is falling apart, she maintains a semblance of composure. Her first impulse after the loss of her lover is to resume her former smoking habit. Her search for cigarettes turns into a road trip that eventually leads to the French heartland.

At one point in the interminable, self-narrated opening, Mr. Workman half-jokingly lists the festivals where his short film played — time that might have been better spent on further exploring Mr. Carbee’s work.
“Bad Words” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A feature-length blue streak.

Every day, the young psychiatrist in Marcelo Gomes’s “Once Upon a Time, Verônica” treats ailing visitors at a public hospital in her city, Recife, Brazil. Some patients can’t quite convey their woes; they seem stymied by an ingrown inability to articulate their problems. The same might be said about their doctor, Verônica, whose rootlessness and vexation Mr. Gomes gingerly records in this poised feature.

Their conflict comes to an ugly head after Christina allows M J to accompany a drug-addicted acquaintance, Rain (Brit Morgan), to a rock concert. Ms. Morgan’s Rain is a frighteningly accurate portrait of a bitter, superannuated groupie on the skids.

“Gone Girl,” the latest from that dark lord of cinema, David Fincher, opens with a man softly talking about his wife’s head. The image of his hand caressing a woman’s sleek blond hair in close-up indicates that it’s a lovely head, a lovely wife, too. Yet the violence of his words — he speaks of cracking her skull open and “unspooling” her brain — wakens an unease that trembles throughout this domestic horror movie. Those familiar with Mr. Fincher’s work may wonder, perhaps with a shudder or a conspiratorial smile, whether this head will share the fate of another head belonging to another pretty wife, a gift that was boxed and delivered in one of the hellish circles girdling his shocker “Seven.”

Some advance publicity is describing “At Middleton” as a romantic comedy, but that is too simplistic a label for this delicate, restrained movie. Yes, it’s full of droll humor, but it’s also a bittersweet portrait of two people, who, in the process of helping their children choose a college, confront the emptiness of their respective marriages.
Directed by Jesse Moss
“Into the Storm” is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for the full wrath of God and computer animation mavens, and some adolescent banter.

Disney’s experience in the animal documentary business (as opposed to the business of talking animated animals) stretches back over half a century. Before there was today’s “Bears” there was “Bear Country,” an Academy Award winner in 1954. The newer ursine chronicle looks at one hungry year in the life of an Alaska mother and her two cubs, with typically simple storytelling and the drumbeat of the hunt for enough food to survive the winter.

Structured in three acts and set in a near-future America in the grip of a lengthy drought, the story (by Mr. Paltrow) introduces a small rural family whose once-fertile land is now dust and rubble. At its head is Ernest (Michael Shannon), an alcoholic in white-knuckle recovery who, helped by his teenage son (Kodi Smit-McPhee), delivers hooch to workers building a pipeline to irrigate corporate farms. Back home, a hostile daughter, Mary (Elle Fanning), frets less about the lack of rain than about the scarcity of frocks and jewelry.

Now considered among the very best of the New York School street photographers, and a leading exponent in the artistic use of color film, Saul Leiter came to this acclaim rather late. While much of his most powerful work was made in the 1950s, it wasn’t truly rediscovered until nearly a half-century later.
Directed by Zachary Wigon

Early in the film, as Eric is sipping a drink at a dusty makeshift cantina, a pickup full of clownish thugs spins out of control on the road. The truck’s occupants help themselves to Eric’s car, which irks him mightily. Since they left behind their own vehicle, which is in fine running order, you might think that he could let the offense go. But that’s not how things work around here; and before long, he has set off in pursuit, in the company of a gutshot nitwit named Rey (Robert Pattinson), whose brother (Scoot McNairy) is one of the car thieves.

But it can’t all be jokes and joints and coitus interruptus. Comedy thrives on conflict, which arrives in the form of that fraternity. The house next door to Kelly and Mac’s is (somewhat improbably, but whatever) purchased by the local college’s chapter of Delta Psi Beta, whose members make the couple feel old and also keep them awake at night with loud music and nonstop debauchery. The president is an abdominally gifted young scholar named Teddy (Mr. Efron), who is determined to make party history, assisted by his best bro, Pete (Dave Franco), and the rest of their brothers. Kelly and Mac try to befriend these dudes, but despite certain shared interests, relations sour quickly.
“Like neighboring warlords in a third world country,” Tanner observes, “they maintained an uneasy balance of power.”

A keen-eyed eager beaver, whom Mr. Madden (“Game of Thrones”) imbues with a sensitivity at times reminiscent of the young Montgomery Clift, Friedrich is a steelworks employee who earned an engineering degree despite having grown up a ward of the state. In contemporary parlance, he is a young man on the make.

“Nuclear Nation” doesn’t take the long view. It doesn’t pretend to be knowledgeable about nuclear power or the politics of the disaster, although the Japanese government and the Tokyo Electric Power Company come off as untrustworthy and indifferent. If nothing else, the film will force you to reassess all the arguments for and against nuclear power.

Of which there are a surprising number in his small desert town. When not assisting the departed, Odd is a short-order cook and adoring boyfriend to Stormy (Addison Timlin), who’s more than tolerant of the shivery gifts he inherited from his institutionalized mother. Dogged by a sympathetic sheriff (Willem Dafoe, barely animate) and a cloud of toothy, gelatinous wraiths, the lovebirds gambol through a plot stuffed to the gills with endangered bowling-alley employees, a gateway to hell and a creep called Fungus Bob (Shuler Hensley) whose refrigerator holds enough fingers and teeth to supply a cannibal edition of “Hoarders.”

Unhappily, the director, Michael Dowse (working from a 2003 play by T. J. Dawe and Michael Rinaldi), remains committed to his rainbows-and-unicorns tone. Wandering around Toronto (romantically filmed by Rogier Stoffers), trapped in the self-conscious one-liners exclusive to quirky rom-coms, Wallace and Chantry are a talky tease. I’d rather have watched Mr. Driver and Ms. Davis lick each other’s skin off any day.

Like “Kai Po Che,” another movie adapted from a novel by Mr. Bhagat, “2 States” is an effort to go beyond formula while also embracing formulaic elements, including some nice song-and-dance sequences. The mix isn’t right yet. But that ambition provides its own tensions and energies, which help “2 States” from feeling becalmed.

By the next month, the British newspaper The Independent had churned out an article on Maier with the waggish, heat-seeking, imprecise headline “Little Miss Big Shot: Fifties America Exposed — by a French Nanny.” (She had a French connection, but there’s more to her than her accent suggests.) More news articles followed, and by January 2011, the Chicago Cultural Center had mounted an exhibition titled “Finding Vivian Maier: Chicago Street Photographer.” The industrious Mr. Maloof, meanwhile, scanned more of her work, bought more of her negatives and started telling his tale and hers, or as much as he knew. Given that this is also a social-media story — Mr. Maloof discovered her, but the Internet made her a star — the Kickstarter campaign to bankroll this documentary was inevitable.

In Paul Haggis’s film “Third Person,” Liam Neeson plays Michael, a Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist who has lost his creative mojo and is holed up in a Paris hotel, completing his latest opus. Accompanying him but staying in a separate suite is his girlfriend, Anna (Olivia Wilde), a wacko celebrity journalist who has literary pretensions that Michael is quick to shoot down. They go at each other with the merciless cruelty of two egotists whose only harmonious moments are bouts of frantic sex.

While wandering through the woods late in the movie, Eric encounters a brown bear. He pets the creature before both go their separate ways. By the end of “Hide Your Smiling Faces,” these boys of summer have blended so thoroughly with their environment that they seem inseparable from the rest of the wildlife.

Goodbye, Elle Woods. Hello, Carrie Davis. The spunky, cutesy-pie go-getter embodied by Reese Witherspoon in the “Legally Blonde” movies has morphed into a still-spirited but somewhat less glamorous do-gooder in “The Good Lie.” Her jaw remains thrust out in an attitude of fierce determination. Her eyes snap with impatience.
A chronicle of her fraught relationship with Argentina’s military dictatorship and her painful exile abroad in the ’70s are recalled, often in her own words, but there is no overview.

“In bondage, she found freedom.” That’s the tagline in the trailer for the Hindi movie “Highway,” and it makes you wonder if the film will be appalling or merely clueless. It’s neither, though it has tone trouble as it searches for a genre to contain a story with built-in believability problems.

The feeling takes hold here and there as a young man, Mark (Robert Olsen), and a self-proclaimed “indigo” teenager, Christina (Isabelle McNally), drift closer but never close enough. Indigo is vaguely defined here as having a certain sensitivity and even power, but the movie doesn’t quite share those qualities, collapsing from a lack of direction in more than one sense.

The credits of “Stalingrad,” a Russian-made 3-D film set during a pivotal battle in World War II, attribute the story to selected chapters from the panoramic novel “Life and Fate” by Vasily Grossman. It’s not the source you might expect for a war movie that uses slow-motion as liberally as a Michael Bay film and that heaves its scream-filled skirmishes onto the arena-size canvas of an Imax screen.

The story is unremarkable, but its execution zings, as an orange tabby is accidentally abandoned and lands in the eccentric home of an elderly magician. Like the toymaker in “Blade Runner,” the magician lives with an assortment of animals and clockwork contraptions — a semi-mechanized family that the cat must win over. This becomes essential when the magician’s weaselly nephew enacts a plan to sell his uncle’s house and turf its owner into a retirement home.

In a device that yields a few easy laughs, the re-enactors insist on period accuracy. (Zoe’s pleas for vegan-friendly food receive a hostile reception.) But “The Discoverers” counters its many contrivances with relaxed pacing and an evocative sense of the American woodlands by bonfire light.

Directed by Judd Ehrlich, “King” has a memorable season’s worth of moving stories to tell on and off the field, as rich as any in “Friday Night Lights.” Most Cougar players come from turbulent, impoverished backgrounds: Dontae Angus, a huge defensive tackle, hopes to get a scholarship to the University of Florida; Sal Henderson, a talented safety and team leader, runs into trouble with the law and misses several games.

As it turns out — as we discover long before Walt does — the author’s own daddy issues are at the heart of her reluctance to play nice in the Disney creative sandbox. “Saving Mr. Banks” toggles between 1961 Burbank and a dusty village in Australia more than half a century before, when the future P. L. Travers was a little girl named Helen Goff (Annie Rose Buckley), nicknamed Ginty by her beloved father (Colin Farrell). An impish, imaginative fellow, he is also a hopeless alcoholic, barely able to hold onto his job managing a bank, and causing his poor wife (Ruth Wilson) no end of worry.
OF THE WORLD

Pierced with touching moments of seemingly stumbled-upon clarity, “Strangers” is a shaggy ode to sibling reconnection. As Matt roams an auditorium during one of his midsong walkabouts, Tom scurries behind with the microphone cable before boosting his brother back onstage. The sequence is wordless, but its metaphorical impact is deafening.
Opens on Friday

Late in the movie, Ms. Johansson’s character appears to become more human and vulnerable after a sexual interlude with a man she picks up. A connection has been made. Her defenses lowered, she finds herself without her fur coat on a hiking trail in the highlands, menaced by a stranger. The movie’s eerie, climactic image challenges our conventional notions of human identity and leaves us reflecting on the possibility that every being in the universe is an alien in disguise.

As they try out various line readings, they never proceed beyond the first scene of Act I, in which the bitter, uncompromisingly moralistic Alceste debates social ethics with Philinte, who preaches civility and discretion in the interests of peaceful coexistence. Many of the actors’ dialogues take place as they bicycle side by side on the picturesque island, where Gauthier is contemplating buying a house.

But Mr. Hanna was confronted by overwhelming forces: family troubles, in the form of his brother Steve, who challenged his hold on the direction of the ranch, and mounting depression, which in 1998 led him to take his own life at 43. A panoply of speakers — including Mr. Schlosser (an executive producer of the film); Steve Hanna; Jay Frost, a half brother; and especially Mr. Hanna’s wife, Ann, a pillar of tender, levelheaded resilience in the face of stark misfortune — flesh out the biographical arc of this innovator. Like many tragic visionaries, Kirk Hanna lives on through his ideas long after his death.

Mirroring Mr. Leiter’s gentle cadences and rhythms, “In No Great Hurry” follows his ambles through his neighborhood, taking pictures. If the film at times seems only a tender profile of a quiet and quirky individual, it is also a meditation of a private life at its end. Everything we see Mr. Leiter doing — cataloging files with his assistant, Margit Erb; organizing the negatives and contact sheets stacked across his home — is part of a summing-up. Mr. Leiter died in November, a week before his 90th birthday and just days after “In No Great Hurry” screened in the Doc NYC film festival. “I think it’s going to be good,” he laughs after seeing a rough cut. Finally, in step with the critics.

One thing that’s missing is a sense of Tagore’s reception in the modern world, beyond concerts and Unesco. Although he is still immensely influential in Bengal and east India, his star has dimmed in the West. Why? The economist Amartya Sen, who appears briefly in the movie, has written elegantly and persuasively on Tagore and that topic. His 1997 article in The New York Review of Books would be an excellent place for interested students to start a study.

Much of the humor in these sequences is, in the modern manner, action-, celebrity-voice-over- and excrement-based, but enough of Ward’s cracked erudition survives to make intellectually insecure grown-ups and precocious children feel smart. The adventures are built to justify the 3-D ticket upcharge, so there is a lot of roller-coasterish swooping and flying and falling. Most of it lacks the sublimity of “Up” or the gravity-defying rush of “How to Train Your Dragon,” but some of the sequences — notably, a flight over Florence in one of Leonardo’s contraptions — are both funny and exciting.

As the film opens, Tom learns that his son’s death was a ritual sacrifice by a cult; he’s told that a similar incident occurred in Providence, R.I. According to an investigating F.B.I. agent (James Naughton), the group has proved difficult for an undercover operative (Quincy Dunn-Baker) to infiltrate. The only question is whether the well-connected Tom, barely punished after attacking one of the cult’s members in a courtroom, will act on his desire to “speed up the process” of capital punishment.

It has all stayed classy, even if it’s not such a big deal anymore. This time, as the ’70s shade into the ’80s, offering new wardrobe and song-cue opportunities, Ron and his pals find themselves present for the birth of 24-hour cable news. Ron and his wife, Veronica Corningstone (Christina Applegate), have a young son (named Walter, as in Cronkite, played by Judah Nelson), but their relationship hits a snag when she is promoted over him at the network that moved them out of San Diego. Ron, his male pride wounded and his professional dignity challenged, goes into a tailspin that is halted when a cable producer (Dylan Baker) recruits him for a new all-news-all-the-time venture. “That’s the stupidest idea I’ve ever heard,” Ron exclaims. That may be the smartest thing he has ever said.

On one level, “Exhibition” is a realistic depiction of a long-term relationship between two people who know each other’s tics so well that they communicate in verbal shorthand. In one excruciatingly honest moment, H asks for sex, and she obliges by showing up, then lying beside him completely inert. Another astoundingly intimate scene shows her masturbating as H sleeps beside her. Both avow their love at various points, but that love doesn’t relieve the tension between them when H interviews D before a live audience, and she refuses to answer his questions.
Directed by Martin Shore

“Planes: Fire & Rescue” introduces the Piston Peak Air Attack Team, which runs emergency missions out of a national park. Its ranks, presumably available in matching Happy Meals, include Dipper (Julie Bowen), an amorous fan of Dusty’s; Windlifter (Wes Studi), a helicopter who speaks a Hollywoodized American Indian argot; and Blade Ranger (Ed Harris), Dusty’s martinet instructor and former star of a ’70s TV series.

The search for the particle itself led to the construction of the Large Hadron Collider at CERN — also called the European Organization for Nuclear Research — near Geneva, where much of the action in “Particle Fever” takes place, in the years leading up to a 2012 breakthrough. At CERN, practical science outstrips the dreams of science fiction as a machine shoots beams of particles around a long track. The hope is that their collisions will provide data indicating the presence of the Higgs.

The meat of the film consists of Vidal’s gloomy thoughts on American history and politics and his conviction that the United States had metamorphosed from a republic into an empire in the thrall of imperialist grandiosity. His estimation of other politicians is devastating: John F. Kennedy was charming and an inspiring speaker but a poor leader who dragged us into Vietnam; Ronald Reagan was “the best cue card reader they could find”; and George W. Bush was a “fool.” About American involvement in the Middle East, he said: “What we’ve done is unite the Muslim world. We’ve made a lot of trouble for ourselves. This is only the beginning, and we will wish we had not done it.”
“Life of Crime” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Kidnapping, racial slurs, some sex.

In the first shot of “Actress,” Robert Greene’s elusive and intriguing new film, Brandy Burre stands at her kitchen sink, wearing a red dress that matches the symmetrically placed poinsettias on the windowsill. In a voice-over, she muses that she is a “type A” personality, which she defines as someone “who breaks things.”

But the directors do have the good sense to let Ms. Demoustier shine at major moments. And when, after a meeting with Vanessa, an exultant Ben is joined spontaneously by a street chorus line dancing to Harry Belafonte’s calypso classic “Jump in the Line,” the movie gives a hint of the dizzying heights it might have attained.
“Hateship Loveship” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex and drug use.

The radical left-wing leader Henri Curiel (who was born in Egypt and later based in Paris) is a crucial figure in these scenes of intrigue. Speculation is presented about his assassination in 1978, yet no solution is offered. In this and other instances, Mr. Ramses’s admirable eagerness to tell a good tale seems to have favored excitement over facts.

Much like the jokes about “22 Jump Street” being a franchise, this kind of doubling flatters the viewer, who, after being pulled in as a paying customer, is recruited as a comedy co-conspirator. (In this way, the movie, naïvely or not, also mimics the academic idea that fans now enjoy unprecedented control of the production and circulation of popular culture.) You’re in on the joke, which makes the movie something you watch and root for. In the first movie, the Jump Street operation is restarted, because, as Chief Hardy explains, “The guys in charge of this stuff lack creativity and are completely out of ideas.” That may have registered as a dig at the studio powers that be, but as the sequel affirms, it’s really a smiling affirmation that the guys in charge know precisely what they are doing.

Ms. Berg’s film followed the case through to its conclusion in 2011, when the defendants were finally released from prison. Under what is known legally as an Alford plea, they formally accepted guilt without admitting they had committed the murders and were set free.
“Walking With Dinosaurs” is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for vivid scary moments of fire and death.

Maybe it’s not credible that two controlling parents would abandon their children in the midst of a college tour and go off on their own adventure of self-discovery, but a piercing scene in which the two adults find themselves in a theater improv class makes the plot device forgivable. This surprise of a film is the first feature for its director, Adam Rodgers (who wrote it with Glenn German), and it’s a fine start.

The film, written and directed by Will Slocombe, looks in on the Thanksgiving of a family presided over by Poppy (Peter Bogdanovich), who spends most of the movie listening to his grown children asking him for money. This particular Thanksgiving is destined for disruption because his daughter Nina (Alicia Witt) has shown up for the first time in years. Another daughter, Lindsay (Sonya Walger), is also on hand, as is their half-brother, Jacob (Ashton Holmes), and Poppy’s second wife (Cheryl Hines).

Several years in the making and seemingly unfolding some hundred years in the past, Aaron Schimberg’s black-and-white pastiche, “Go Down Death,” is a curious foray into lo-fi anachronism. Shot on 16-millimeter film, this staccato ensemble of vignettes shuffles among the fatalistic inhabitants of a run-down hamlet who have little to cling to but crackerjack philosophizing.

Eric and Neville sometimes meet in group sessions organized by Oliver (Rupert Friend), a therapist whose attempts to help the inmates work out their issues with words rather than fists are looked on by the prison governors with condescending tolerance or contempt, depending on how many fights they have been called in to break up lately.
Opens on Friday

A grumpy old man and a dotty old lady share a moment of late-life bliss in the geriatric romantic comedy “Elsa & Fred.” Because that fun couple are played by Christopher Plummer and Shirley MacLaine, the movie’s too-cute concept yields more rewards than you might reasonably expect.
“Begin Again” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A few swear words, but otherwise pretty much what you’d hear over the speakers at Starbucks.

As far as formal-dress chamber dramas go, that approach wouldn’t necessarily be a fatal blow for this adaptation. Mr. Ramsay, who also plays the title role as a mildly dissipated young man, sees Hamlet’s unhappy homecoming as a ripe opportunity for confrontations and confidences in darkened corridors, which it surely can be. But the play’s examination of interiority (and acknowledgment of its unknowns) loses its richness in this scaled-down version. Hamlet himself feels ever-present yet diluted, while Ophelia (Lara Gilchrist) and, to a lesser extent, Gertrude (Gillian Barber) are given greater dimensions.
LEFT BEHIND

In case you’re not already nodding in agreement, several dozen celebrities, game developers and other worthies are waiting to twist your arm. Pallid dudes surrounded by dorm-room décor rhapsodize over their first console and the discovery of game-playing soul mates. (One man — perhaps misconnecting the medical dots — even credits gaming for his recovery from a stroke.)
Directed by Isaac Hertz

The songs, from Mr. Carney, Gregg Alexander and others, are strings of lyrical and instrumental commonplaces. That’s true of a lot of pop classics, of course, which enliven the tried and true with fresh and surprising notes. “Begin Again” has some of those, especially when Mr. Ruffalo shambles into Ms. Keener’s company. It also handles the possible sexual connection between Dan and Gretta with Henry Jamesian discretion, avoiding creepiness without denying the magnetic attraction that pulses beneath their shared interests.

In its brazen bawdiness, the movie resembles “That Awkward Moment,” the loathsome new sex comedy starring Zac Efron as a smug young Lothario stalking Manhattan. But “Love & Air Sex” has a spontaneity and cheeky attitude lacking in Mr. Efron’s film, along with spirited naturalistic performances that infuse the standard rom-com formula with a zany vitality.
Opens on Wednesday

It all takes place in the fictional Scandinavian land of Arendelle, whose king and queen die in a shipwreck, leaving the country in the hands of Elsa (the voice of Idina Menzel), the elder of two daughters. This blond, high-strung princess has a secret problem. If she isn’t extremely careful, everything around her freezes when she takes off her protective gloves and waves her hands. Elsa’s best friend is her impulsive redheaded younger sister, Anna (Kristen Bell), whom she nearly freezes to death by accident.

It’s a high school football tale (the title is one of the team’s running plays), inspired by a true story but taking too many liberties with it. Travis Freeman (Mark Hapka), a student in Corbin, Ky., loses his eyesight to a disease, but with the encouragement of a grizzled coach (Stephen Lang) and a no-nonsense mobility therapist (Becky Ann Baker), he continues playing football.
Opens on Friday

Like a companion piece to Cevin Soling’s provocative 2009 documentary, “The War on Kids,” this new investigation reveals the heartbreaking consequences of abused power. In the end, we may be troubled less by the events on screen than by the fear that they’re being replayed all over the country.

Not long after Nadia serves them coffee in her family’s parlor, Amjad, Omar and Tarek, militants affiliated with the Aksa Martyrs Brigades, carry out a sniper attack on an Israeli military outpost. This act, partly meant as a proof of manhood, leads to a series of tragic and sometimes absurd events that ensnare everyone, but especially Omar, in a web of conflicting loyalties and motives. To describe Omar’s circumstances as a dilemma would be much too simple, though at first, he seems to face a stark choice between equally intolerable options. Arrested and imprisoned, Omar is told by Rami (Waleed Zuaiter), the Israeli officer handling his case, that he can either cooperate and inform on his friends or spend the rest of his life locked up far away from Nadia and everyone else he cares about. Though Omar tries to find a way out of this predicament, the Israelis are always a step ahead of him, and everyone back home assumes that he has already turned collaborator.

I know, I couldn’t believe it either. Mr. Taylor-Johnson, who was the pretty-boy Vronsky in “Anna Karenina” and the avenging nerd in the “Kick-Ass” movies, reports for duty as a muscly military guy whose family business is mixed up with Godzilla’s. His name is Ford Brody, and his parents (Bryan Cranston and Juliette Binoche, a dream couple if ever there was one) were engineers at a Japanese nuclear plant where something went very wrong in 1999. Now, 15 years later, Ford’s dad has become a wild-eyed truther, the walls of his tiny Tokyo apartment plastered with newspaper clippings and charts. He’s convinced that whatever happened at his former workplace was no natural disaster.

Yet, shot in burnished tones by the cinematographer Giovani Lampassi, the movie exudes a low-key warmth. Luann gets liquored up with Boyd’s mother (Candice Bergen, in a nice turn). Virgil — still so unhinged that he serves squirrel to his returning son and yells, “Is your name on the mailbox?” to assert his authority — instantly turns from vicious to sad. It’s the screenwriter’s equivalent of a holiday miracle.

The film’s other insurmountable problem is the compression of its story. The anguish of the lovers’ decade-long separation can’t be evoked in a matter of minutes, and when Friedrich returns looking pretty much unchanged except for a limp, it’s as though he took a week’s working vacation and came home more exhausted than when he left.

“Affluenza” flashes back one month. Fisher moves in with his aunt (Samantha Mathis) and uncle (Steve Guttenberg). Their high-school-age daughter, Kate (Nicola Peltz), dates Todd (Grant Gustin), heir to a real estate fortune, but has a history with the nouveau riche Dylan (Gregg Sulkin), who promises to grease Fisher’s school transfer for help in wooing Kate.

The director Hossein Amini sets up all these pieces and looks, these covert glances and hushed exchanges, with economy and borderline geometric precision. Working from his adaptation of the 1964 Patricia Highsmith novel, he doesn’t build unease; rather, he smartly leads with it, a storytelling strategy that quickly muddies up this otherwise bright, clean world. (His other credits include screen adaptations of “Jude” and “The Wings of the Dove.”) The unease grows, seeping into every word and gesture. One evening after dinner, Rydal returns to Chester and Colette’s hotel and sees Chester dragging a man’s body. Stunned, Rydal offers his help and at that moment graduates from interested observer to guilty participant. It’s as if he were willing himself off a cliff.

His director, however, proves better at designing self-contained scenes than solid characters, leaving us with a tasting menu of hard-man predicaments that never offer more than a pale introduction to the innocent mark flailing at their center.

At times, the faces of the actors under his command register confusion and frustration. Mr. Brook’s words can flow almost effortlessly from plain practicality — stand here; walk that way; start again — to dizzying abstraction. His presence is both calm and intense, and, like all the best teachers, he offers lessons that can hardly be absorbed, much less applied, all at once. You envy his disciples, even as you may also feel a twinge of sympathy when their sincere best efforts fall short.

It’s a glimpse of another culture in the totally counterproductive form of confusingly wretched comedy, broken up by moments of instructive domestic tension. Mr. Rosebiani evidently wants to avoid depressing his audience while addressing a serious subject, but his aims are likely to be lost in this film’s strained mugging.

The cash, the clichés — it’s hard not to be impatient with a movie as openly lazy as “Cold Comes the Night,” which is redeemed only by its performances. Strangely, the one exception is Mr. Cranston, who, hidden behind amber-tinted glasses and speaking in a Boris-and-Natasha monotone, brings a few deep-freeze shivers but mostly seems to have checked out before “Action!” was called. As a cop, Logan Marshall-Green works hard to enliven his scenes and does, and Robin Taylor amuses in a disposable role as a driver. As luscious as risen cream, Ms. Eve holds your attention easily enough but also surprises by adding nasty to the nice. As it turns out, she has a deliciously sinister smile that, however briefly, may make you think of Ann Savage in Edgar G. Ulmer’s classic downer “Detour.”

The filmmaker, Sylvia Caminer, is trying to work the contrast, but Ms. Kenney is so uninformed and shallow that it defies credulity. “I haven’t had to overcome anything, compared to these people,” she says at one point, as if thinking the thought for the first time.

You can admire what he does without really enjoying it, and two hours and 46 minutes of pulverized architecture is a lot to endure. But in every Michael Bay movie there are at least a few moments of inspired, kinetic absurdity. Late in “Age of Extinction,” a giant spaceship hovering over Hong Kong, equipped with some kind of magnet, sucks up a lot of vehicles — buses, trucks, fishing boats, ferries, whatever — and drops them onto the city below. I could not tell you exactly why, because it doesn’t matter, but the sequence is both exciting and revealing. It reminds you what these movies are really about: a boy at play, reveling in the creative and destructive power, and the glorious uselessness, of his own imagination.

These scenes have explosive dramatic potential, but they aren’t sufficiently developed to convey the sense of tragic inevitability that underlies the story. The characters aren’t properly introduced, and as the increasingly choppy film zigzags among several subplots, you long for a dramatic grounding wire as compelling as Melissa Leo in “Frozen River,” an equally bleak film set in similar border territory.

Aiming to capture a time when you’re just envisioning a life, “God Help the Girl” (which began as a 2009 album) has a childlike innocence that showcases Mr. Murdoch’s ethereal songs. Belle and Sebastian fans will be fully sated; everyone else might feel as if they’d consumed a meal consisting entirely of meringue.

The biggest mistake of “Blood Ties” is its dawdling momentum. Despite some spurts of action, the screenplay, by Mr. Canet and James Gray, slows for moments of reflection that don’t add depth; they just add to the excessive running time.

Inside every milquetoast beats the heart of a tiger waiting to be released. All it takes to liberate the beast is a beautiful, seductive woman whose wiles can turn a mouse into a man. So goes the hoary, misogynist pop myth that drives “Better Living Through Chemistry,” a tepid but pleasant comic satire given a shot of contemporaneity by its writing and directing team, Geoff Moore and David Posamentier, and its star Sam Rockwell.
Opens on Friday.

The first faces on screen at a recent advance showing of “The Hundred-Foot Journey” belonged to Oprah Winfrey and Steven Spielberg, who do not appear in the movie itself but are credited among its producers. It’s a bit unusual to be subjected to a promo trying to sell you on a movie you have already committed to seeing, but Mr. Spielberg and Ms. Winfrey clearly could not contain themselves, and took a moment to share their enthusiasm. In the clip (which has also aired on television), Ms. Winfrey, using the trademark falsetto singsong that is her version of conversational italics, tells us how excited she is to present this amazing movie, while Mr. Spielberg uses variations on the word “incredible” at least three times. Noting that “The Hundred-Foot Journey,” based on a popular novel by Richard C. Morais, is about food, Ms. Winfrey asks, “Can I say it’s delicious?”
“A Walk Among the Tombstones” is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence.

Mr. Dhulia’s story bounces around, sometimes strangely, but always keeps an eye on the object of its affection, Raja Mishra (Saif Ali Khan), a solemn hero who has little personality beyond his muscles and manhood.
